para.personname: HUMPHREY, Duke of Gloucester, his uncle.
CARDINAL BEAUFORT, Bishop of Winchester, great-uncle to the King.
WILLIAM STAFFORD, Sir Humphrey Stafford's brother.
QUEEN MARGARET, Queen to King Henry.
Lords, Ladies, and Attendants. Petitioners, Aldermen, a Herald, a Beadle, Sheriff, and Officers, Citizens, 'Prentices, Falconers, Guards, Soldiers, Messengers, &c.

section.title: SCENE I. London. The palace.
section.para: Flourish of trumpets: then hautboys. Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, SALISBURY, WARWICK, and CARDINAL, on the one side; QUEEN MARGARET, SUFFOLK, YORK, SOMERSET, and BUCKINGHAM, on the other

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: As by your high imperial majesty
I had in charge at my depart for France,
As procurator to your excellence,
To marry Princess Margaret for your grace,
So, in the famous ancient city, Tours,
In presence of the Kings of France and Sicil,
The Dukes of Orleans, Calaber, Bretagne and Alencon,
Seven earls, twelve barons and twenty reverend bishops,
I have perform'd my task and was espoused:
And humbly now upon my bended knee,
In sight of England and her lordly peers,
Deliver up my title in the queen
To your most gracious hands, that are the substance
Of that great shadow I did represent;
The happiest gift that ever marquess gave,
The fairest queen that ever king received.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Suffolk, arise. Welcome, Queen Margaret:
I can express no kinder sign of love
Than this kind kiss. O Lord, that lends me life,
Lend me a heart replete with thankfulness!
For thou hast given me in this beauteous face
A world of earthly blessings to my soul,
If sympathy of love unite our thoughts.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Great King of England and my gracious lord,
The mutual conference that my mind hath had,
By day, by night, waking and in my dreams,
In courtly company or at my beads,
With you, mine alder-liefest sovereign,
Makes me the bolder to salute my king
With ruder terms, such as my wit affords
And over-joy of heart doth minister.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Her sight did ravish; but her grace in speech,
Her words y-clad with wisdom's majesty,
Makes me from wondering fall to weeping joys;
Such is the fulness of my heart's content.
Lords, with one cheerful voice welcome my love.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: Kneeling Long live Queen Margaret, England's
happiness!

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: We thank you all.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: My lord protector, so it please your grace,
Here are the articles of contracted peace
Between our sovereign and the French king Charles,
For eighteen months concluded by consent.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Reads 'Imprimis, it is agreed between the French
king Charles, and William de la Pole, Marquess of
Suffolk, ambassador for Henry King of England, that
the said Henry shall espouse the Lady Margaret,
daughter unto Reignier King of Naples, Sicilia and
Jerusalem, and crown her Queen of England ere the
thirtieth of May next ensuing. Item, that the duchy
of Anjou and the county of Maine shall be released
and delivered to the king her father'--

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Uncle, how now!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Pardon me, gracious lord;
Some sudden qualm hath struck me at the heart
And dimm'd mine eyes, that I can read no further.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Uncle of Winchester, I pray, read on.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Reads 'Item, It is further agreed between them,
that the duchies of Anjou and Maine shall be
released and delivered over to the king her father,
and she sent over of the King of England's own
proper cost and charges, without having any dowry.'

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: They please us well. Lord marquess, kneel down:
We here create thee the first duke of Suffolk,
And gird thee with the sword. Cousin of York,
We here discharge your grace from being regent
I' the parts of France, till term of eighteen months
Be full expired. Thanks, uncle Winchester,
Gloucester, York, Buckingham, Somerset,
Salisbury, and Warwick;
We thank you all for the great favour done,
In entertainment to my princely queen.
Come, let us in, and with all speed provide
To see her coronation be perform'd.

section.para: Exeunt KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, and SUFFOLK

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Brave peers of England, pillars of the state,
To you Duke Humphrey must unload his grief,
Your grief, the common grief of all the land.
What! did my brother Henry spend his youth,
His valour, coin and people, in the wars?
Did he so often lodge in open field,
In winter's cold and summer's parching heat,
To conquer France, his true inheritance?
And did my brother Bedford toil his wits,
To keep by policy what Henry got?
Have you yourselves, Somerset, Buckingham,
Brave York, Salisbury, and victorious Warwick,
Received deep scars in France and Normandy?
Or hath mine uncle Beaufort and myself,
With all the learned council of the realm,
Studied so long, sat in the council-house
Early and late, debating to and fro
How France and Frenchmen might be kept in awe,
And had his highness in his infancy
Crowned in Paris in despite of foes?
And shall these labours and these honours die?
Shall Henry's conquest, Bedford's vigilance,
Your deeds of war and all our counsel die?
O peers of England, shameful is this league!
Fatal this marriage, cancelling your fame,
Blotting your names from books of memory,
Razing the characters of your renown,
Defacing monuments of conquer'd France,
Undoing all, as all had never been!

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Nephew, what means this passionate discourse,
This peroration with such circumstance?
For France, 'tis ours; and we will keep it still.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Ay, uncle, we will keep it, if we can;
But now it is impossible we should:
Suffolk, the new-made duke that rules the roast,
Hath given the duchy of Anjou and Maine
Unto the poor King Reignier, whose large style
Agrees not with the leanness of his purse.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: Now, by the death of Him that died for all,
These counties were the keys of Normandy.
But wherefore weeps Warwick, my valiant son?

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: For grief that they are past recovery:
For, were there hope to conquer them again,
My sword should shed hot blood, mine eyes no tears.
Anjou and Maine! myself did win them both;
Those provinces these arms of mine did conquer:
And are the cities, that I got with wounds,
Delivered up again with peaceful words?
Mort Dieu!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: For Suffolk's duke, may he be suffocate,
That dims the honour of this warlike isle!
France should have torn and rent my very heart,
Before I would have yielded to this league.
I never read but England's kings have had
Large sums of gold and dowries with their wives:
And our King Henry gives away his own,
To match with her that brings no vantages.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: A proper jest, and never heard before,
That Suffolk should demand a whole fifteenth
For costs and charges in transporting her!
She should have stayed in France and starved
in France, Before--

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: My Lord of Gloucester, now ye grow too hot:
It was the pleasure of my lord the King.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: My Lord of Winchester, I know your mind;
'Tis not my speeches that you do mislike,
But 'tis my presence that doth trouble ye.
Rancour will out: proud prelate, in thy face
I see thy fury: if I longer stay,
We shall begin our ancient bickerings.
Lordings, farewell; and say, when I am gone,
I prophesied France will be lost ere long.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: So, there goes our protector in a rage.
'Tis known to you he is mine enemy,
Nay, more, an enemy unto you all,
And no great friend, I fear me, to the king.
Consider, lords, he is the next of blood,
And heir apparent to the English crown:
Had Henry got an empire by his marriage,
And all the wealthy kingdoms of the west,
There's reason he should be displeased at it.
Look to it, lords! let not his smoothing words
Bewitch your hearts; be wise and circumspect.
What though the common people favour him,
Calling him 'Humphrey, the good Duke of
Gloucester,'
Clapping their hands, and crying with loud voice,
'Jesu maintain your royal excellence!'
With 'God preserve the good Duke Humphrey!'
I fear me, lords, for all this flattering gloss,
He will be found a dangerous protector.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Why should he, then, protect our sovereign,
He being of age to govern of himself?
Cousin of Somerset, join you with me,
And all together, with the Duke of Suffolk,
We'll quickly hoise Duke Humphrey from his seat.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: This weighty business will not brook delay:
I'll to the Duke of Suffolk presently.

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: Cousin of Buckingham, though Humphrey's pride
And greatness of his place be grief to us,
Yet let us watch the haughty cardinal:
His insolence is more intolerable
Than all the princes in the land beside:
If Gloucester be displaced, he'll be protector.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Or thou or I, Somerset, will be protector,
Despite Duke Humphrey or the cardinal.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: Pride went before, ambition follows him.
While these do labour for their own preferment,
Behoves it us to labour for the realm.
I never saw but Humphrey Duke of Gloucester
Did bear him like a noble gentleman.
Oft have I seen the haughty cardinal,
More like a soldier than a man o' the church,
As stout and proud as he were lord of all,
Swear like a ruffian and demean himself
Unlike the ruler of a commonweal.
Warwick, my son, the comfort of my age,
Thy deeds, thy plainness and thy housekeeping,
Hath won the greatest favour of the commons,
Excepting none but good Duke Humphrey:
And, brother York, thy acts in Ireland,
In bringing them to civil discipline,
Thy late exploits done in the heart of France,
When thou wert regent for our sovereign,
Have made thee fear'd and honour'd of the people:
Join we together, for the public good,
In what we can, to bridle and suppress
The pride of Suffolk and the cardinal,
With Somerset's and Buckingham's ambition;
And, as we may, cherish Duke Humphrey's deeds,
While they do tend the profit of the land.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: So God help Warwick, as he loves the land,
And common profit of his country!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Aside And so says York, for he hath greatest cause.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: Then let's make haste away, and look unto the main.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Unto the main! O father, Maine is lost;
That Maine which by main force Warwick did win,
And would have kept so long as breath did last!
Main chance, father, you meant; but I meant Maine,
Which I will win from France, or else be slain,

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Anjou and Maine are given to the French;
Paris is lost; the state of Normandy
Stands on a tickle point, now they are gone:
Suffolk concluded on the articles,
The peers agreed, and Henry was well pleased
To change two dukedoms for a duke's fair daughter.
I cannot blame them all: what is't to them?
'Tis thine they give away, and not their own.
Pirates may make cheap pennyworths of their pillage
And purchase friends and give to courtezans,
Still revelling like lords till all be gone;
While as the silly owner of the goods
Weeps over them and wrings his hapless hands
And shakes his head and trembling stands aloof,
While all is shared and all is borne away,
Ready to starve and dare not touch his own:
So York must sit and fret and bite his tongue,
While his own lands are bargain'd for and sold.
Methinks the realms of England, France and Ireland
Bear that proportion to my flesh and blood
As did the fatal brand Althaea burn'd
Unto the prince's heart of Calydon.
Anjou and Maine both given unto the French!
Cold news for me, for I had hope of France,
Even as I have of fertile England's soil.
A day will come when York shall claim his own;
And therefore I will take the Nevils' parts
And make a show of love to proud Duke Humphrey,
And, when I spy advantage, claim the crown,
For that's the golden mark I seek to hit:
Nor shall proud Lancaster usurp my right,
Nor hold the sceptre in his childish fist,
Nor wear the diadem upon his head,
Whose church-like humours fits not for a crown.
Then, York, be still awhile, till time do serve:
Watch thou and wake when others be asleep,
To pry into the secrets of the state;
Till Henry, surfeiting in joys of love,
With his new bride and England's dear-bought queen,
And Humphrey with the peers be fall'n at jars:
Then will I raise aloft the milk-white rose,
With whose sweet smell the air shall be perfumed;
And in my standard bear the arms of York
To grapple with the house of Lancaster;
And, force perforce, I'll make him yield the crown,
Whose bookish rule hath pull'd fair England down.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Why droops my lord, like over-ripen'd corn,
Hanging the head at Ceres' plenteous load?
Why doth the great Duke Humphrey knit his brows,
As frowning at the favours of the world?
Why are thine eyes fixed to the sullen earth,
Gazing on that which seems to dim thy sight?
What seest thou there? King Henry's diadem,
Enchased with all the honours of the world?
If so, gaze on, and grovel on thy face,
Until thy head be circled with the same.
Put forth thy hand, reach at the glorious gold.
What, is't too short? I'll lengthen it with mine:
And, having both together heaved it up,
We'll both together lift our heads to heaven,
And never more abase our sight so low
As to vouchsafe one glance unto the ground.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: O Nell, sweet Nell, if thou dost love thy lord,
Banish the canker of ambitious thoughts.
And may that thought, when I imagine ill
Against my king and nephew, virtuous Henry,
Be my last breathing in this mortal world!
My troublous dream this night doth make me sad.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: What dream'd my lord? tell me, and I'll requite it
With sweet rehearsal of my morning's dream.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Methought this staff, mine office-badge in court,
Was broke in twain; by whom I have forgot,
But, as I think, it was by the cardinal;
And on the pieces of the broken wand
Were placed the heads of Edmund Duke of Somerset,
And William de la Pole, first duke of Suffolk.
This was my dream: what it doth bode, God knows.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Tut, this was nothing but an argument
That he that breaks a stick of Gloucester's grove
Shall lose his head for his presumption.
But list to me, my Humphrey, my sweet duke:
Methought I sat in seat of majesty
In the cathedral church of Westminster,
And in that chair where kings and queens are crown'd;
Where Henry and dame Margaret kneel'd to me
And on my head did set the diadem.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Nay, Eleanor, then must I chide outright:
Presumptuous dame, ill-nurtured Eleanor,
Art thou not second woman in the realm,
And the protector's wife, beloved of him?
Hast thou not worldly pleasure at command,
Above the reach or compass of thy thought?
And wilt thou still be hammering treachery,
To tumble down thy husband and thyself
From top of honour to disgrace's feet?
Away from me, and let me hear no more!

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: What, what, my lord! are you so choleric
With Eleanor, for telling but her dream?
Next time I'll keep my dreams unto myself,
And not be cheque'd.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Nay, be not angry; I am pleased again.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: My lord protector, 'tis his highness' pleasure
You do prepare to ride unto Saint Alban's,
Where as the king and queen do mean to hawk.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: I go. Come, Nell, thou wilt ride with us?

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Yes, my good lord, I'll follow presently.
Follow I must; I cannot go before,
While Gloucester bears this base and humble mind.
Were I a man, a duke, and next of blood,
I would remove these tedious stumbling-blocks
And smooth my way upon their headless necks;
And, being a woman, I will not be slack
To play my part in Fortune's pageant.
Where are you there? Sir John! nay, fear not, man,
We are alone; here's none but thee and I.

linegroup.speaker: HUME
linegroup.line: Jesus preserve your royal majesty!

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: What say'st thou? majesty! I am but grace.

linegroup.speaker: HUME
linegroup.line: But, by the grace of God, and Hume's advice,
Your grace's title shall be multiplied.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: What say'st thou, man? hast thou as yet conferr'd
With Margery Jourdain, the cunning witch,
With Roger Bolingbroke, the conjurer?
And will they undertake to do me good?

linegroup.speaker: HUME
linegroup.line: This they have promised, to show your highness
A spirit raised from depth of under-ground,
That shall make answer to such questions
As by your grace shall be propounded him.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: It is enough; I'll think upon the questions:
When from St. Alban's we do make return,
We'll see these things effected to the full.
Here, Hume, take this reward; make merry, man,
With thy confederates in this weighty cause.

linegroup.speaker: HUME
linegroup.line: Hume must make merry with the duchess' gold;
Marry, and shall. But how now, Sir John Hume!
Seal up your lips, and give no words but mum:
The business asketh silent secrecy.
Dame Eleanor gives gold to bring the witch:
Gold cannot come amiss, were she a devil.
Yet have I gold flies from another coast;
I dare not say, from the rich cardinal
And from the great and new-made Duke of Suffolk,
Yet I do find it so; for to be plain,
They, knowing Dame Eleanor's aspiring humour,
Have hired me to undermine the duchess
And buz these conjurations in her brain.
They say 'A crafty knave does need no broker;'
Yet am I Suffolk and the cardinal's broker.
Hume, if you take not heed, you shall go near
To call them both a pair of crafty knaves.
Well, so it stands; and thus, I fear, at last
Hume's knavery will be the duchess' wreck,
And her attainture will be Humphrey's fall:
Sort how it will, I shall have gold for all.

section.title: SCENE III. The palace.
section.para: Enter three or four Petitioners, PETER, the Armourer's man, being one

linegroup.speaker: First Petitioner
linegroup.line: My masters, let's stand close: my lord protector
will come this way by and by, and then we may deliver
our supplications in the quill.

linegroup.speaker: Second Petitioner
linegroup.line: Marry, the Lord protect him, for he's a good man!
Jesu bless him!

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: Here a' comes, methinks, and the queen with him.
I'll be the first, sure.

linegroup.speaker: Second Petitioner
linegroup.line: Come back, fool; this is the Duke of Suffolk, and
not my lord protector.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: How now, fellow! would'st anything with me?

linegroup.speaker: First Petitioner
linegroup.line: I pray, my lord, pardon me; I took ye for my lord
protector.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Reading 'To my Lord Protector!' Are your
supplications to his lordship? Let me see them:
what is thine?

linegroup.speaker: First Petitioner
linegroup.line: Mine is, an't please your grace, against John
Goodman, my lord cardinal's man, for keeping my
house, and lands, and wife and all, from me.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Thy wife, too! that's some wrong, indeed. What's
yours? What's here!
'Against the Duke of Suffolk, for enclosing the
commons of Melford.' How now, sir knave!

linegroup.speaker: Second Petitioner
linegroup.line: Alas, sir, I am but a poor petitioner of our whole township.

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: Giving his petition Against my master, Thomas
Horner, for saying that the Duke of York was rightful
heir to the crown.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: What sayst thou? did the Duke of York say he was
rightful heir to the crown?

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: That my master was? no, forsooth: my master said
that he was, and that the king was an usurper.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Who is there?
Take this fellow in, and send for
his master with a pursuivant presently: we'll hear
more of your matter before the King.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: And as for you, that love to be protected
Under the wings of our protector's grace,
Begin your suits anew, and sue to him.
Away, base cullions! Suffolk, let them go.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: Come, let's be gone.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: My Lord of Suffolk, say, is this the guise,
Is this the fashion in the court of England?
Is this the government of Britain's isle,
And this the royalty of Albion's king?
What shall King Henry be a pupil still
Under the surly Gloucester's governance?
Am I a queen in title and in style,
And must be made a subject to a duke?
I tell thee, Pole, when in the city Tours
Thou ran'st a tilt in honour of my love
And stolest away the ladies' hearts of France,
I thought King Henry had resembled thee
In courage, courtship and proportion:
But all his mind is bent to holiness,
To number Ave-Maries on his beads;
His champions are the prophets and apostles,
His weapons holy saws of sacred writ,
His study is his tilt-yard, and his loves
Are brazen images of canonized saints.
I would the college of the cardinals
Would choose him pope, and carry him to Rome,
And set the triple crown upon his head:
That were a state fit for his holiness.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Madam, be patient: as I was cause
Your highness came to England, so will I
In England work your grace's full content.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Beside the haughty protector, have we Beaufort,
The imperious churchman, Somerset, Buckingham,
And grumbling York: and not the least of these
But can do more in England than the king.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: And he of these that can do most of all
Cannot do more in England than the Nevils:
Salisbury and Warwick are no simple peers.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Not all these lords do vex me half so much
As that proud dame, the lord protector's wife.
She sweeps it through the court with troops of ladies,
More like an empress than Duke Humphrey's wife:
Strangers in court do take her for the queen:
She bears a duke's revenues on her back,
And in her heart she scorns our poverty:
Shall I not live to be avenged on her?
Contemptuous base-born callet as she is,
She vaunted 'mongst her minions t'other day,
The very train of her worst wearing gown
Was better worth than all my father's lands,
Till Suffolk gave two dukedoms for his daughter.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Madam, myself have limed a bush for her,
And placed a quire of such enticing birds,
That she will light to listen to the lays,
And never mount to trouble you again.
So, let her rest: and, madam, list to me;
For I am bold to counsel you in this.
Although we fancy not the cardinal,
Yet must we join with him and with the lords,
Till we have brought Duke Humphrey in disgrace.
As for the Duke of York, this late complaint
Will make but little for his benefit.
So, one by one, we'll weed them all at last,
And you yourself shall steer the happy helm.

section.para: Sound a sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, CARDINAL, BUCKINGHAM, YORK, SOMERSET, SALISBURY, WARWICK, and the DUCHESS

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: For my part, noble lords, I care not which;
Or Somerset or York, all's one to me.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: If York have ill demean'd himself in France,
Then let him be denay'd the regentship.

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: If Somerset be unworthy of the place,
Let York be regent; I will yield to him.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Whether your grace be worthy, yea or no,
Dispute not that: York is the worthier.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Ambitious Warwick, let thy betters speak.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: The cardinal's not my better in the field.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: All in this presence are thy betters, Warwick.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Warwick may live to be the best of all.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: Peace, son! and show some reason, Buckingham,
Why Somerset should be preferred in this.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Because the king, forsooth, will have it so.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Madam, the king is old enough himself
To give his censure: these are no women's matters.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: If he be old enough, what needs your grace
To be protector of his excellence?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Madam, I am protector of the realm;
And, at his pleasure, will resign my place.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Resign it then and leave thine insolence.
Since thou wert king--as who is king but thou?--
The commonwealth hath daily run to wreck;
The Dauphin hath prevail'd beyond the seas;
And all the peers and nobles of the realm
Have been as bondmen to thy sovereignty.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: The commons hast thou rack'd; the clergy's bags
Are lank and lean with thy extortions.

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: Thy sumptuous buildings and thy wife's attire
Have cost a mass of public treasury.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Thy cruelty in execution
Upon offenders, hath exceeded law,
And left thee to the mercy of the law.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: They sale of offices and towns in France,
If they were known, as the suspect is great,
Would make thee quickly hop without thy head.
linegroup.para: Exit GLOUCESTER. QUEEN MARGARET drops her fan
linegroup.line: Give me my fan: what, minion! can ye not?
linegroup.para: She gives the DUCHESS a box on the ear
linegroup.line: I cry you mercy, madam; was it you?

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Was't I! yea, I it was, proud Frenchwoman:
Could I come near your beauty with my nails,
I'd set my ten commandments in your face.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Sweet aunt, be quiet; 'twas against her will.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Against her will! good king, look to't in time;
She'll hamper thee, and dandle thee like a baby:
Though in this place most master wear no breeches,
She shall not strike Dame Eleanor unrevenged.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Lord cardinal, I will follow Eleanor,
And listen after Humphrey, how he proceeds:
She's tickled now; her fume needs no spurs,
She'll gallop far enough to her destruction.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Now, lords, my choler being over-blown
With walking once about the quadrangle,
I come to talk of commonwealth affairs.
As for your spiteful false objections,
Prove them, and I lie open to the law:
But God in mercy so deal with my soul,
As I in duty love my king and country!
But, to the matter that we have in hand:
I say, my sovereign, York is meetest man
To be your regent in the realm of France.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Before we make election, give me leave
To show some reason, of no little force,
That York is most unmeet of any man.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: I'll tell thee, Suffolk, why I am unmeet:
First, for I cannot flatter thee in pride;
Next, if I be appointed for the place,
My Lord of Somerset will keep me here,
Without discharge, money, or furniture,
Till France be won into the Dauphin's hands:
Last time, I danced attendance on his will
Till Paris was besieged, famish'd, and lost.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: That can I witness; and a fouler fact
Did never traitor in the land commit.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Peace, headstrong Warwick!

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Image of pride, why should I hold my peace?

section.para: Enter HORNER, the Armourer, and his man PETER, guarded

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Because here is a man accused of treason:
Pray God the Duke of York excuse himself!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Doth any one accuse York for a traitor?

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: What mean'st thou, Suffolk; tell me, what are these?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Please it your majesty, this is the man
That doth accuse his master of high treason:
His words were these: that Richard, Duke of York,
Was rightful heir unto the English crown
And that your majesty was a usurper.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Say, man, were these thy words?

linegroup.speaker: HORNER
linegroup.line: An't shall please your majesty, I never said nor
thought any such matter: God is my witness, I am
falsely accused by the villain.

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: By these ten bones, my lords, he did speak them to
me in the garret one night, as we were scouring my
Lord of York's armour.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Base dunghill villain and mechanical,
I'll have thy head for this thy traitor's speech.
I do beseech your royal majesty,
Let him have all the rigor of the law.

linegroup.speaker: HORNER
linegroup.line: Alas, my lord, hang me, if ever I spake the words.
My accuser is my 'prentice; and when I did correct
him for his fault the other day, he did vow upon his
knees he would be even with me: I have good
witness of this: therefore I beseech your majesty,
do not cast away an honest man for a villain's
accusation.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Uncle, what shall we say to this in law?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: This doom, my lord, if I may judge:
Let Somerset be regent over the French,
Because in York this breeds suspicion:
And let these have a day appointed them
For single combat in convenient place,
For he hath witness of his servant's malice:
This is the law, and this Duke Humphrey's doom.

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: I humbly thank your royal majesty.

linegroup.speaker: HORNER
linegroup.line: And I accept the combat willingly.

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: Alas, my lord, I cannot fight; for God's sake, pity
my case. The spite of man prevaileth against me. O
Lord, have mercy upon me! I shall never be able to
fight a blow. O Lord, my heart!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Sirrah, or you must fight, or else be hang'd.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Away with them to prison; and the day of combat
shall be the last of the next month. Come,
Somerset, we'll see thee sent away.

section.title: SCENE IV. GLOUCESTER's garden.
section.para: Enter MARGARET JOURDAIN, HUME, SOUTHWELL, and BOLINGBROKE

linegroup.speaker: HUME
linegroup.line: Come, my masters; the duchess, I tell you, expects
performance of your promises.

linegroup.speaker: BOLINGBROKE
linegroup.line: Master Hume, we are therefore provided: will her
ladyship behold and hear our exorcisms?

linegroup.speaker: HUME
linegroup.line: Ay, what else? fear you not her courage.

linegroup.speaker: BOLINGBROKE
linegroup.line: I have heard her reported to be a woman of an
invincible spirit: but it shall be convenient,
Master Hume, that you be by her aloft, while we be
busy below; and so, I pray you, go, in God's name,
and leave us.
Mother Jourdain, be you
prostrate and grovel on the earth; John Southwell,
read you; and let us to our work.

section.para: Enter the DUCHESS aloft, HUME following

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Well said, my masters; and welcome all. To this
gear the sooner the better.

linegroup.speaker: BOLINGBROKE
linegroup.line: Patience, good lady; wizards know their times:
Deep night, dark night, the silent of the night,
The time of night when Troy was set on fire;
The time when screech-owls cry and ban-dogs howl,
And spirits walk and ghosts break up their graves,
That time best fits the work we have in hand.
Madam, sit you and fear not: whom we raise,
We will make fast within a hallow'd verge.

section.para: Here they do the ceremonies belonging, and make the circle; BOLINGBROKE or SOUTHWELL reads, Conjuro te, &c. It thunders and lightens terribly; then the Spirit riseth

linegroup.speaker: Spirit
linegroup.line: Adsum.

linegroup.speaker: MARGARET JOURDAIN
linegroup.line: Asmath,
By the eternal God, whose name and power
Thou tremblest at, answer that I shall ask;
For, till thou speak, thou shalt not pass from hence.

linegroup.speaker: Spirit
linegroup.line: Ask what thou wilt. That I had said and done!

linegroup.speaker: BOLINGBROKE
linegroup.line: 'First of the king: what shall of him become?'

linegroup.speaker: Spirit
linegroup.line: The duke yet lives that Henry shall depose;
But him outlive, and die a violent death.

section.para: As the Spirit speaks, SOUTHWELL writes the answer

linegroup.speaker: BOLINGBROKE
linegroup.line: 'What fates await the Duke of Suffolk?'

linegroup.speaker: Spirit
linegroup.line: By water shall he die, and take his end.

linegroup.speaker: BOLINGBROKE
linegroup.line: 'What shall befall the Duke of Somerset?'

linegroup.speaker: Spirit
linegroup.line: Let him shun castles;
Safer shall he be upon the sandy plains
Than where castles mounted stand.
Have done, for more I hardly can endure.

linegroup.speaker: BOLINGBROKE
linegroup.line: Descend to darkness and the burning lake!
False fiend, avoid!

section.para: Enter YORK and BUCKINGHAM with their Guard and break in

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Lay hands upon these traitors and their trash.
Beldam, I think we watch'd you at an inch.
What, madam, are you there? the king and commonweal
Are deeply indebted for this piece of pains:
My lord protector will, I doubt it not,
See you well guerdon'd for these good deserts.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Not half so bad as thine to England's king,
Injurious duke, that threatest where's no cause.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: True, madam, none at all: what call you this?
Away with them! let them be clapp'd up close.
And kept asunder. You, madam, shall with us.
Stafford, take her to thee.
linegroup.para: Exeunt above DUCHESS and HUME, guarded
linegroup.line: We'll see your trinkets here all forthcoming.
All, away!

section.para: Exeunt guard with MARGARET JOURDAIN, SOUTHWELL, &c

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Lord Buckingham, methinks, you watch'd her well:
A pretty plot, well chosen to build upon!
Now, pray, my lord, let's see the devil's writ.
What have we here?
'The duke yet lives, that Henry shall depose;
But him outlive, and die a violent death.'
Why, this is just
'Aio te, AEacida, Romanos vincere posse.'
Well, to the rest:
'Tell me what fate awaits the Duke of Suffolk?
By water shall he die, and take his end.
What shall betide the Duke of Somerset?
Let him shun castles;
Safer shall he be upon the sandy plains
Than where castles mounted stand.'
Come, come, my lords;
These oracles are hardly attain'd,
And hardly understood.
The king is now in progress towards Saint Alban's,
With him the husband of this lovely lady:
Thither go these news, as fast as horse can
carry them:
A sorry breakfast for my lord protector.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Your grace shall give me leave, my Lord of York,
To be the post, in hope of his reward.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: At your pleasure, my good lord. Who's within
there, ho!
Invite my Lords of Salisbury and Warwick
To sup with me to-morrow night. Away!

section.title: SCENE I. Saint Alban's.
section.para: Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, GLOUCESTER, CARDINAL, and SUFFOLK, with Falconers halloing

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Believe me, lords, for flying at the brook,
I saw not better sport these seven years' day:
Yet, by your leave, the wind was very high;
And, ten to one, old Joan had not gone out.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: But what a point, my lord, your falcon made,
And what a pitch she flew above the rest!
To see how God in all his creatures works!
Yea, man and birds are fain of climbing high.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: No marvel, an it like your majesty,
My lord protector's hawks do tower so well;
They know their master loves to be aloft,
And bears his thoughts above his falcon's pitch.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: My lord, 'tis but a base ignoble mind
That mounts no higher than a bird can soar.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: I thought as much; he would be above the clouds.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Ay, my lord cardinal? how think you by that?
Were it not good your grace could fly to heaven?

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: The treasury of everlasting joy.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Thy heaven is on earth; thine eyes and thoughts
Beat on a crown, the treasure of thy heart;
Pernicious protector, dangerous peer,
That smooth'st it so with king and commonweal!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What, cardinal, is your priesthood grown peremptory?
Tantaene animis coelestibus irae?
Churchmen so hot? good uncle, hide such malice;
With such holiness can you do it?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: No malice, sir; no more than well becomes
So good a quarrel and so bad a peer.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: As who, my lord?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Why, as you, my lord,
An't like your lordly lord-protectorship.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Why, Suffolk, England knows thine insolence.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: And thy ambition, Gloucester.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: I prithee, peace, good queen,
And whet not on these furious peers;
For blessed are the peacemakers on earth.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Let me be blessed for the peace I make,
Against this proud protector, with my sword!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Aside to CARDINAL Faith, holy uncle, would
'twere come to that!

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Aside to GLOUCESTER Marry, when thou darest.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Aside to CARDINAL Make up no factious
numbers for the matter;
In thine own person answer thy abuse.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Aside to GLOUCESTER Ay, where thou darest
not peep: an if thou darest,
This evening, on the east side of the grove.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: How now, my lords!

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Believe me, cousin Gloucester,
Had not your man put up the fowl so suddenly,
We had had more sport.
Come with thy two-hand sword.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: True, uncle.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Aside to GLOUCESTER Are ye advised? the
east side of the grove?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Aside to CARDINAL Cardinal, I am with you.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Why, how now, uncle Gloucester!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Talking of hawking; nothing else, my lord.
Now, by God's mother, priest, I'll shave your crown for this,
Or all my fence shall fail.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Aside to GLOUCESTER Medice, teipsum--
Protector, see to't well, protect yourself.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: The winds grow high; so do your stomachs, lords.
How irksome is this music to my heart!
When such strings jar, what hope of harmony?
I pray, my lords, let me compound this strife.

section.para: Enter a Townsman of Saint Alban's, crying 'A miracle!'

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What means this noise?
Fellow, what miracle dost thou proclaim?

linegroup.speaker: Townsman
linegroup.line: A miracle! a miracle!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Come to the king and tell him what miracle.

linegroup.speaker: Townsman
linegroup.line: Forsooth, a blind man at Saint Alban's shrine,
Within this half-hour, hath received his sight;
A man that ne'er saw in his life before.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Now, God be praised, that to believing souls
Gives light in darkness, comfort in despair!

section.para: Enter the Mayor of Saint Alban's and his brethren, bearing SIMPCOX, between two in a chair, SIMPCOX's Wife following

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Here comes the townsmen on procession,
To present your highness with the man.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Great is his comfort in this earthly vale,
Although by his sight his sin be multiplied.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Stand by, my masters: bring him near the king;
His highness' pleasure is to talk with him.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Good fellow, tell us here the circumstance,
That we for thee may glorify the Lord.
What, hast thou been long blind and now restored?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Born blind, an't please your grace.

linegroup.speaker: Wife
linegroup.line: Ay, indeed, was he.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: What woman is this?

linegroup.speaker: Wife
linegroup.line: His wife, an't like your worship.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Hadst thou been his mother, thou couldst have
better told.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Where wert thou born?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: At Berwick in the north, an't like your grace.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Poor soul, God's goodness hath been great to thee:
Let never day nor night unhallow'd pass,
But still remember what the Lord hath done.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Tell me, good fellow, camest thou here by chance,
Or of devotion, to this holy shrine?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: God knows, of pure devotion; being call'd
A hundred times and oftener, in my sleep,
By good Saint Alban; who said, 'Simpcox, come,
Come, offer at my shrine, and I will help thee.'

linegroup.speaker: Wife
linegroup.line: Most true, forsooth; and many time and oft
Myself have heard a voice to call him so.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: What, art thou lame?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Ay, God Almighty help me!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: How camest thou so?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: A fall off of a tree.

linegroup.speaker: Wife
linegroup.line: A plum-tree, master.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: How long hast thou been blind?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Born so, master.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What, and wouldst climb a tree?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: But that in all my life, when I was a youth.

linegroup.speaker: Wife
linegroup.line: Too true; and bought his climbing very dear.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Mass, thou lovedst plums well, that wouldst
venture so.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Alas, good master, my wife desired some damsons,
And made me climb, with danger of my life.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: A subtle knave! but yet it shall not serve.
Let me see thine eyes: wink now: now open them:
In my opinion yet thou seest not well.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Yes, master, clear as day, I thank God and
Saint Alban.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Say'st thou me so? What colour is this cloak of?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Red, master; red as blood.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Why, that's well said. What colour is my gown of?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Black, forsooth: coal-black as jet.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Why, then, thou know'st what colour jet is of?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: And yet, I think, jet did he never see.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: But cloaks and gowns, before this day, a many.

linegroup.speaker: Wife
linegroup.line: Never, before this day, in all his life.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Tell me, sirrah, what's my name?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Alas, master, I know not.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What's his name?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: I know not.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Nor his?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: No, indeed, master.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What's thine own name?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Saunder Simpcox, an if it please you, master.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Then, Saunder, sit there, the lyingest knave in
Christendom. If thou hadst been born blind, thou
mightest as well have known all our names as thus to
name the several colours we do wear. Sight may
distinguish of colours, but suddenly to nominate them
all, it is impossible. My lords, Saint Alban here
hath done a miracle; and would ye not think his
cunning to be great, that could restore this cripple
to his legs again?

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: O master, that you could!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: My masters of Saint Alban's, have you not beadles in
your town, and things called whips?

linegroup.speaker: Mayor
linegroup.line: Yes, my lord, if it please your grace.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Then send for one presently.

linegroup.speaker: Mayor
linegroup.line: Sirrah, go fetch the beadle hither straight.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Now fetch me a stool hither by and by. Now, sirrah,
if you mean to save yourself from whipping, leap me
over this stool and run away.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Alas, master, I am not able to stand alone:
You go about to torture me in vain.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Well, sir, we must have you find your legs. Sirrah
beadle, whip him till he leap over that same stool.

linegroup.speaker: Beadle
linegroup.line: I will, my lord. Come on, sirrah; off with your
doublet quickly.

linegroup.speaker: SIMPCOX
linegroup.line: Alas, master, what shall I do? I am not able to stand.

section.para: After the Beadle hath hit him once, he leaps over the stool and runs away; and they follow and cry, 'A miracle!'

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: O God, seest Thou this, and bearest so long?

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: It made me laugh to see the villain run.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Follow the knave; and take this drab away.

linegroup.speaker: Wife
linegroup.line: Alas, sir, we did it for pure need.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Let them be whipped through every market-town, till
they come to Berwick, from whence they came.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Duke Humphrey has done a miracle to-day.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: True; made the lame to leap and fly away.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: But you have done more miracles than I;
You made in a day, my lord, whole towns to fly.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: What tidings with our cousin Buckingham?

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Such as my heart doth tremble to unfold.
A sort of naughty persons, lewdly bent,
Under the countenance and confederacy
Of Lady Eleanor, the protector's wife,
The ringleader and head of all this rout,
Have practised dangerously against your state,
Dealing with witches and with conjurers:
Whom we have apprehended in the fact;
Raising up wicked spirits from under ground,
Demanding of King Henry's life and death,
And other of your highness' privy-council;
As more at large your grace shall understand.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Aside to GLOUCESTER And so, my lord protector,
by this means
Your lady is forthcoming yet at London.
This news, I think, hath turn'd your weapon's edge;
'Tis like, my lord, you will not keep your hour.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Ambitious churchman, leave to afflict my heart:
Sorrow and grief have vanquish'd all my powers;
And, vanquish'd as I am, I yield to thee,
Or to the meanest groom.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: O God, what mischiefs work the wicked ones,
Heaping confusion on their own heads thereby!

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Gloucester, see here the tainture of thy nest.
And look thyself be faultless, thou wert best.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Madam, for myself, to heaven I do appeal,
How I have loved my king and commonweal:
And, for my wife, I know not how it stands;
Sorry I am to hear what I have heard:
Noble she is, but if she have forgot
Honour and virtue and conversed with such
As, like to pitch, defile nobility,
I banish her my bed and company
And give her as a prey to law and shame,
That hath dishonour'd Gloucester's honest name.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Well, for this night we will repose us here:
To-morrow toward London back again,
To look into this business thoroughly
And call these foul offenders to their answers
And poise the cause in justice' equal scales,
Whose beam stands sure, whose rightful cause prevails.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Now, my good Lords of Salisbury and Warwick,
Our simple supper ended, give me leave
In this close walk to satisfy myself,
In craving your opinion of my title,
Which is infallible, to England's crown.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: My lord, I long to hear it at full.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Sweet York, begin: and if thy claim be good,
The Nevils are thy subjects to command.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Then thus:
Edward the Third, my lords, had seven sons:
The first, Edward the Black Prince, Prince of Wales;
The second, William of Hatfield, and the third,
Lionel Duke of Clarence: next to whom
Was John of Gaunt, the Duke of Lancaster;
The fifth was Edmund Langley, Duke of York;
The sixth was Thomas of Woodstock, Duke of Gloucester;
William of Windsor was the seventh and last.
Edward the Black Prince died before his father
And left behind him Richard, his only son,
Who after Edward the Third's death reign'd as king;
Till Henry Bolingbroke, Duke of Lancaster,
The eldest son and heir of John of Gaunt,
Crown'd by the name of Henry the Fourth,
Seized on the realm, deposed the rightful king,
Sent his poor queen to France, from whence she came,
And him to Pomfret; where, as all you know,
Harmless Richard was murder'd traitorously.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Father, the duke hath told the truth:
Thus got the house of Lancaster the crown.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Which now they hold by force and not by right;
For Richard, the first son's heir, being dead,
The issue of the next son should have reign'd.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: But William of Hatfield died without an heir.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: The third son, Duke of Clarence, from whose line
I claimed the crown, had issue, Philippe, a daughter,
Who married Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March:
Edmund had issue, Roger Earl of March;
Roger had issue, Edmund, Anne and Eleanor.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: This Edmund, in the reign of Bolingbroke,
As I have read, laid claim unto the crown;
And, but for Owen Glendower, had been king,
Who kept him in captivity till he died.
But to the rest.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: His eldest sister, Anne,
My mother, being heir unto the crown
Married Richard Earl of Cambridge; who was son
To Edmund Langley, Edward the Third's fifth son.
By her I claim the kingdom: she was heir
To Roger Earl of March, who was the son
Of Edmund Mortimer, who married Philippe,
Sole daughter unto Lionel Duke of Clarence:
So, if the issue of the elder son
Succeed before the younger, I am king.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: What plain proceeding is more plain than this?
Henry doth claim the crown from John of Gaunt,
The fourth son; York claims it from the third.
Till Lionel's issue fails, his should not reign:
It fails not yet, but flourishes in thee
And in thy sons, fair slips of such a stock.
Then, father Salisbury, kneel we together;
And in this private plot be we the first
That shall salute our rightful sovereign
With honour of his birthright to the crown.

linegroup.speaker: BOTH
linegroup.line: Long live our sovereign Richard, England's king!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: We thank you, lords. But I am not your king
Till I be crown'd and that my sword be stain'd
With heart-blood of the house of Lancaster;
And that's not suddenly to be perform'd,
But with advice and silent secrecy.
Do you as I do in these dangerous days:
Wink at the Duke of Suffolk's insolence,
At Beaufort's pride, at Somerset's ambition,
At Buckingham and all the crew of them,
Till they have snared the shepherd of the flock,
That virtuous prince, the good Duke Humphrey:
'Tis that they seek, and they in seeking that
Shall find their deaths, if York can prophesy.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: My lord, break we off; we know your mind at full.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: My heart assures me that the Earl of Warwick
Shall one day make the Duke of York a king.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: And, Nevil, this I do assure myself:
Richard shall live to make the Earl of Warwick
The greatest man in England but the king.

section.title: SCENE III. A hall of justice.
section.para: Sound trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, GLOUCESTER, YORK, SUFFOLK, and SALISBURY; the DUCHESS, MARGARET JOURDAIN, SOUTHWELL, HUME, and BOLINGBROKE, under guard

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Stand forth, Dame Eleanor Cobham, Gloucester's wife:
In sight of God and us, your guilt is great:
Receive the sentence of the law for sins
Such as by God's book are adjudged to death.
You four, from hence to prison back again;
From thence unto the place of execution:
The witch in Smithfield shall be burn'd to ashes,
And you three shall be strangled on the gallows.
You, madam, for you are more nobly born,
Despoiled of your honour in your life,
Shall, after three days' open penance done,
Live in your country here in banishment,
With Sir John Stanley, in the Isle of Man.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Welcome is banishment; welcome were my death.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Eleanor, the law, thou see'st, hath judged thee:
I cannot justify whom the law condemns.
linegroup.para: Exeunt DUCHESS and other prisoners, guarded
linegroup.line: Mine eyes are full of tears, my heart of grief.
Ah, Humphrey, this dishonour in thine age
Will bring thy head with sorrow to the ground!
I beseech your majesty, give me leave to go;
Sorrow would solace and mine age would ease.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Stay, Humphrey Duke of Gloucester: ere thou go,
Give up thy staff: Henry will to himself
Protector be; and God shall be my hope,
My stay, my guide and lantern to my feet:
And go in peace, Humphrey, no less beloved
Than when thou wert protector to thy King.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: I see no reason why a king of years
Should be to be protected like a child.
God and King Henry govern England's realm.
Give up your staff, sir, and the king his realm.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: My staff? here, noble Henry, is my staff:
As willingly do I the same resign
As e'er thy father Henry made it mine;
And even as willingly at thy feet I leave it
As others would ambitiously receive it.
Farewell, good king: when I am dead and gone,
May honourable peace attend thy throne!

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Why, now is Henry king, and Margaret queen;
And Humphrey Duke of Gloucester scarce himself,
That bears so shrewd a maim; two pulls at once;
His lady banish'd, and a limb lopp'd off.
This staff of honour raught, there let it stand
Where it best fits to be, in Henry's hand.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Thus droops this lofty pine and hangs his sprays;
Thus Eleanor's pride dies in her youngest days.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Lords, let him go. Please it your majesty,
This is the day appointed for the combat;
And ready are the appellant and defendant,
The armourer and his man, to enter the lists,
So please your highness to behold the fight.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Ay, good my lord; for purposely therefore
Left I the court, to see this quarrel tried.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: O God's name, see the lists and all things fit:
Here let them end it; and God defend the right!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: I never saw a fellow worse bested,
Or more afraid to fight, than is the appellant,
The servant of this armourer, my lords.

section.para: Enter at one door, HORNER, the Armourer, and his Neighbours, drinking to him so much that he is drunk; and he enters with a drum before him and his staff with a sand-bag fastened to it; and at the other door PETER, his man, with a drum and sand-bag, and 'Prentices drinking to him

linegroup.speaker: First Neighbour
linegroup.line: Here, neighbour Horner, I drink to you in a cup of
sack: and fear not, neighbour, you shall do well enough.

linegroup.speaker: Second Neighbour
linegroup.line: And here, neighbour, here's a cup of charneco.

linegroup.speaker: Third Neighbour
linegroup.line: And here's a pot of good double beer, neighbour:
drink, and fear not your man.

linegroup.speaker: HORNER
linegroup.line: Let it come, i' faith, and I'll pledge you all; and
a fig for Peter!

linegroup.speaker: First 'Prentice
linegroup.line: Here, Peter, I drink to thee: and be not afraid.

linegroup.speaker: Second 'Prentice
linegroup.line: Be merry, Peter, and fear not thy master: fight
for credit of the 'prentices.

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: I thank you all: drink, and pray for me, I pray
you; for I think I have taken my last draught in
this world. Here, Robin, an if I die, I give thee
my apron: and, Will, thou shalt have my hammer:
and here, Tom, take all the money that I have. O
Lord bless me! I pray God! for I am never able to
deal with my master, he hath learnt me so much fence already.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: Come, leave your drinking, and fall to blows.
Sirrah, what's thy name?

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: Peter, forsooth.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: Peter! what more?

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: Thump.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: Thump! then see thou thump thy master well.

linegroup.speaker: HORNER
linegroup.line: Masters, I am come hither, as it were, upon my man's
instigation, to prove him a knave and myself an
honest man: and touching the Duke of York, I will
take my death, I never meant him any ill, nor the
king, nor the queen: and therefore, Peter, have at
thee with a downright blow!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Dispatch: this knave's tongue begins to double.
Sound, trumpets, alarum to the combatants!

section.para: Alarum. They fight, and PETER strikes him down

linegroup.speaker: HORNER
linegroup.line: Hold, Peter, hold! I confess, I confess treason.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Take away his weapon. Fellow, thank God, and the
good wine in thy master's way.

linegroup.speaker: PETER
linegroup.line: O God, have I overcome mine enemy in this presence?
O Peter, thou hast prevailed in right!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Go, take hence that traitor from our sight;
For his death we do perceive his guilt:
And God in justice hath revealed to us
The truth and innocence of this poor fellow,
Which he had thought to have murder'd wrongfully.
Come, fellow, follow us for thy reward.

section.title: SCENE IV. A street.
section.para: Enter GLOUCESTER and his Servingmen, in mourning cloaks

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Thus sometimes hath the brightest day a cloud;
And after summer evermore succeeds
Barren winter, with his wrathful nipping cold:
So cares and joys abound, as seasons fleet.
Sirs, what's o'clock?

linegroup.speaker: Servants
linegroup.line: Ten, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Ten is the hour that was appointed me
To watch the coming of my punish'd duchess:
Uneath may she endure the flinty streets,
To tread them with her tender-feeling feet.
Sweet Nell, ill can thy noble mind abrook
The abject people gazing on thy face,
With envious looks, laughing at thy shame,
That erst did follow thy proud chariot-wheels
When thou didst ride in triumph through the streets.
But, soft! I think she comes; and I'll prepare
My tear-stain'd eyes to see her miseries.

section.para: Enter the DUCHESS in a white sheet, and a taper burning in her hand; with STANLEY, the Sheriff, and Officers

linegroup.speaker: Servant
linegroup.line: So please your grace, we'll take her from the sheriff.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: No, stir not, for your lives; let her pass by.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Come you, my lord, to see my open shame?
Now thou dost penance too. Look how they gaze!
See how the giddy multitude do point,
And nod their heads, and throw their eyes on thee!
Ah, Gloucester, hide thee from their hateful looks,
And, in thy closet pent up, rue my shame,
And ban thine enemies, both mine and thine!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Be patient, gentle Nell; forget this grief.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Ah, Gloucester, teach me to forget myself!
For whilst I think I am thy married wife
And thou a prince, protector of this land,
Methinks I should not thus be led along,
Mail'd up in shame, with papers on my back,
And followed with a rabble that rejoice
To see my tears and hear my deep-fet groans.
The ruthless flint doth cut my tender feet,
And when I start, the envious people laugh
And bid me be advised how I tread.
Ah, Humphrey, can I bear this shameful yoke?
Trow'st thou that e'er I'll look upon the world,
Or count them happy that enjoy the sun?
No; dark shall be my light and night my day;
To think upon my pomp shall be my hell.
Sometime I'll say, I am Duke Humphrey's wife,
And he a prince and ruler of the land:
Yet so he ruled and such a prince he was
As he stood by whilst I, his forlorn duchess,
Was made a wonder and a pointing-stock
To every idle rascal follower.
But be thou mild and blush not at my shame,
Nor stir at nothing till the axe of death
Hang over thee, as, sure, it shortly will;
For Suffolk, he that can do all in all
With her that hateth thee and hates us all,
And York and impious Beaufort, that false priest,
Have all limed bushes to betray thy wings,
And, fly thou how thou canst, they'll tangle thee:
But fear not thou, until thy foot be snared,
Nor never seek prevention of thy foes.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Ah, Nell, forbear! thou aimest all awry;
I must offend before I be attainted;
And had I twenty times so many foes,
And each of them had twenty times their power,
All these could not procure me any scathe,
So long as I am loyal, true and crimeless.
Wouldst have me rescue thee from this reproach?
Why, yet thy scandal were not wiped away
But I in danger for the breach of law.
Thy greatest help is quiet, gentle Nell:
I pray thee, sort thy heart to patience;
These few days' wonder will be quickly worn.

linegroup.speaker: Herald
linegroup.line: I summon your grace to his majesty's parliament,
Holden at Bury the first of this next month.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: And my consent ne'er ask'd herein before!
This is close dealing. Well, I will be there.
My Nell, I take my leave: and, master sheriff,
Let not her penance exceed the king's commission.

linegroup.speaker: Sheriff
linegroup.line: An't please your grace, here my commission stays,
And Sir John Stanley is appointed now
To take her with him to the Isle of Man.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Must you, Sir John, protect my lady here?

linegroup.speaker: STANLEY
linegroup.line: So am I given in charge, may't please your grace.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Entreat her not the worse in that I pray
You use her well: the world may laugh again;
And I may live to do you kindness if
You do it her: and so, Sir John, farewell!

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: What, gone, my lord, and bid me not farewell!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Witness my tears, I cannot stay to speak.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Art thou gone too? all comfort go with thee!
For none abides with me: my joy is death;
Death, at whose name I oft have been afear'd,
Because I wish'd this world's eternity.
Stanley, I prithee, go, and take me hence;
I care not whither, for I beg no favour,
Only convey me where thou art commanded.

linegroup.speaker: STANLEY
linegroup.line: Why, madam, that is to the Isle of Man;
There to be used according to your state.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: That's bad enough, for I am but reproach:
And shall I then be used reproachfully?

linegroup.speaker: STANLEY
linegroup.line: Like to a duchess, and Duke Humphrey's lady;
According to that state you shall be used.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Sheriff, farewell, and better than I fare,
Although thou hast been conduct of my shame.

linegroup.speaker: Sheriff
linegroup.line: It is my office; and, madam, pardon me.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: Ay, ay, farewell; thy office is discharged.
Come, Stanley, shall we go?

linegroup.speaker: STANLEY
linegroup.line: Madam, your penance done, throw off this sheet,
And go we to attire you for our journey.

linegroup.speaker: DUCHESS
linegroup.line: My shame will not be shifted with my sheet:
No, it will hang upon my richest robes
And show itself, attire me how I can.
Go, lead the way; I long to see my prison.

section.title: SCENE I. The Abbey at Bury St. Edmund's.
section.para: Sound a sennet. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, CARDINAL, SUFFOLK, YORK, BUCKINGHAM, SALISBURY and WARWICK to the Parliament

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: I muse my Lord of Gloucester is not come:
'Tis not his wont to be the hindmost man,
Whate'er occasion keeps him from us now.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Can you not see? or will ye not observe
The strangeness of his alter'd countenance?
With what a majesty he bears himself,
How insolent of late he is become,
How proud, how peremptory, and unlike himself?
We know the time since he was mild and affable,
And if we did but glance a far-off look,
Immediately he was upon his knee,
That all the court admired him for submission:
But meet him now, and, be it in the morn,
When every one will give the time of day,
He knits his brow and shows an angry eye,
And passeth by with stiff unbowed knee,
Disdaining duty that to us belongs.
Small curs are not regarded when they grin;
But great men tremble when the lion roars;
And Humphrey is no little man in England.
First note that he is near you in descent,
And should you fall, he as the next will mount.
Me seemeth then it is no policy,
Respecting what a rancorous mind he bears
And his advantage following your decease,
That he should come about your royal person
Or be admitted to your highness' council.
By flattery hath he won the commons' hearts,
And when he please to make commotion,
'Tis to be fear'd they all will follow him.
Now 'tis the spring, and weeds are shallow-rooted;
Suffer them now, and they'll o'ergrow the garden
And choke the herbs for want of husbandry.
The reverent care I bear unto my lord
Made me collect these dangers in the duke.
If it be fond, call it a woman's fear;
Which fear if better reasons can supplant,
I will subscribe and say I wrong'd the duke.
My Lord of Suffolk, Buckingham, and York,
Reprove my allegation, if you can;
Or else conclude my words effectual.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Well hath your highness seen into this duke;
And, had I first been put to speak my mind,
I think I should have told your grace's tale.
The duchess, by his subornation,
Upon my life, began her devilish practises:
Or, if he were not privy to those faults,
Yet, by reputing of his high descent,
As next the king he was successive heir,
And such high vaunts of his nobility,
Did instigate the bedlam brain-sick duchess
By wicked means to frame our sovereign's fall.
Smooth runs the water where the brook is deep;
And in his simple show he harbours treason.
The fox barks not when he would steal the lamb.
No, no, my sovereign; Gloucester is a man
Unsounded yet and full of deep deceit.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Did he not, contrary to form of law,
Devise strange deaths for small offences done?

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: And did he not, in his protectorship,
Levy great sums of money through the realm
For soldiers' pay in France, and never sent it?
By means whereof the towns each day revolted.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Tut, these are petty faults to faults unknown.
Which time will bring to light in smooth
Duke Humphrey.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: My lords, at once: the care you have of us,
To mow down thorns that would annoy our foot,
Is worthy praise: but, shall I speak my conscience,
Our kinsman Gloucester is as innocent
From meaning treason to our royal person
As is the sucking lamb or harmless dove:
The duke is virtuous, mild and too well given
To dream on evil or to work my downfall.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Ah, what's more dangerous than this fond affiance!
Seems he a dove? his feathers are but borrowed,
For he's disposed as the hateful raven:
Is he a lamb? his skin is surely lent him,
For he's inclined as is the ravenous wolf.
Who cannot steal a shape that means deceit?
Take heed, my lord; the welfare of us all
Hangs on the cutting short that fraudful man.

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: All health unto my gracious sovereign!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Welcome, Lord Somerset. What news from France?

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: That all your interest in those territories
Is utterly bereft you; all is lost.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Cold news, Lord Somerset: but God's will be done!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Aside Cold news for me; for I had hope of France
As firmly as I hope for fertile England.
Thus are my blossoms blasted in the bud
And caterpillars eat my leaves away;
But I will remedy this gear ere long,
Or sell my title for a glorious grave.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: All happiness unto my lord the king!
Pardon, my liege, that I have stay'd so long.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Nay, Gloucester, know that thou art come too soon,
Unless thou wert more loyal than thou art:
I do arrest thee of high treason here.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Well, Suffolk, thou shalt not see me blush
Nor change my countenance for this arrest:
A heart unspotted is not easily daunted.
The purest spring is not so free from mud
As I am clear from treason to my sovereign:
Who can accuse me? wherein am I guilty?

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: 'Tis thought, my lord, that you took bribes of France,
And, being protector, stayed the soldiers' pay;
By means whereof his highness hath lost France.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Is it but thought so? what are they that think it?
I never robb'd the soldiers of their pay,
Nor ever had one penny bribe from France.
So help me God, as I have watch'd the night,
Ay, night by night, in studying good for England,
That doit that e'er I wrested from the king,
Or any groat I hoarded to my use,
Be brought against me at my trial-day!
No; many a pound of mine own proper store,
Because I would not tax the needy commons,
Have I disbursed to the garrisons,
And never ask'd for restitution.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: It serves you well, my lord, to say so much.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: I say no more than truth, so help me God!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: In your protectorship you did devise
Strange tortures for offenders never heard of,
That England was defamed by tyranny.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Why, 'tis well known that, whiles I was
protector,
Pity was all the fault that was in me;
For I should melt at an offender's tears,
And lowly words were ransom for their fault.
Unless it were a bloody murderer,
Or foul felonious thief that fleeced poor passengers,
I never gave them condign punishment:
Murder indeed, that bloody sin, I tortured
Above the felon or what trespass else.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: My lord, these faults are easy, quickly answered:
But mightier crimes are laid unto your charge,
Whereof you cannot easily purge yourself.
I do arrest you in his highness' name;
And here commit you to my lord cardinal
To keep, until your further time of trial.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: My lord of Gloucester, 'tis my special hope
That you will clear yourself from all suspect:
My conscience tells me you are innocent.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Ah, gracious lord, these days are dangerous:
Virtue is choked with foul ambition
And charity chased hence by rancour's hand;
Foul subornation is predominant
And equity exiled your highness' land.
I know their complot is to have my life,
And if my death might make this island happy,
And prove the period of their tyranny,
I would expend it with all willingness:
But mine is made the prologue to their play;
For thousands more, that yet suspect no peril,
Will not conclude their plotted tragedy.
Beaufort's red sparkling eyes blab his heart's malice,
And Suffolk's cloudy brow his stormy hate;
Sharp Buckingham unburthens with his tongue
The envious load that lies upon his heart;
And dogged York, that reaches at the moon,
Whose overweening arm I have pluck'd back,
By false accuse doth level at my life:
And you, my sovereign lady, with the rest,
Causeless have laid disgraces on my head,
And with your best endeavour have stirr'd up
My liefest liege to be mine enemy:
Ay, all you have laid your heads together--
Myself had notice of your conventicles--
And all to make away my guiltless life.
I shall not want false witness to condemn me,
Nor store of treasons to augment my guilt;
The ancient proverb will be well effected:
'A staff is quickly found to beat a dog.'

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: My liege, his railing is intolerable:
If those that care to keep your royal person
From treason's secret knife and traitors' rage
Be thus upbraided, chid and rated at,
And the offender granted scope of speech,
'Twill make them cool in zeal unto your grace.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Hath he not twit our sovereign lady here
With ignominious words, though clerkly couch'd,
As if she had suborned some to swear
False allegations to o'erthrow his state?

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: But I can give the loser leave to chide.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Far truer spoke than meant: I lose, indeed;
Beshrew the winners, for they play'd me false!
And well such losers may have leave to speak.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: He'll wrest the sense and hold us here all day:
Lord cardinal, he is your prisoner.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Sirs, take away the duke, and guard him sure.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Ah! thus King Henry throws away his crutch
Before his legs be firm to bear his body.
Thus is the shepherd beaten from thy side,
And wolves are gnarling who shall gnaw thee first.
Ah, that my fear were false! ah, that it were!
For, good King Henry, thy decay I fear.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: My lords, what to your wisdoms seemeth best,
Do or undo, as if ourself were here.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: What, will your highness leave the parliament?

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Ay, Margaret; my heart is drown'd with grief,
Whose flood begins to flow within mine eyes,
My body round engirt with misery,
For what's more miserable than discontent?
Ah, uncle Humphrey! in thy face I see
The map of honour, truth and loyalty:
And yet, good Humphrey, is the hour to come
That e'er I proved thee false or fear'd thy faith.
What louring star now envies thy estate,
That these great lords and Margaret our queen
Do seek subversion of thy harmless life?
Thou never didst them wrong, nor no man wrong;
And as the butcher takes away the calf
And binds the wretch, and beats it when it strays,
Bearing it to the bloody slaughter-house,
Even so remorseless have they borne him hence;
And as the dam runs lowing up and down,
Looking the way her harmless young one went,
And can do nought but wail her darling's loss,
Even so myself bewails good Gloucester's case
With sad unhelpful tears, and with dimm'd eyes
Look after him and cannot do him good,
So mighty are his vowed enemies.
His fortunes I will weep; and, 'twixt each groan
Say 'Who's a traitor? Gloucester he is none.'

section.para: Exeunt all but QUEEN MARGARET, CARDINAL, SUFFOLK, and YORK; SOMERSET remains apart

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Free lords, cold snow melts with the sun's hot beams.
Henry my lord is cold in great affairs,
Too full of foolish pity, and Gloucester's show
Beguiles him as the mournful crocodile
With sorrow snares relenting passengers,
Or as the snake roll'd in a flowering bank,
With shining chequer'd slough, doth sting a child
That for the beauty thinks it excellent.
Believe me, lords, were none more wise than I--
And yet herein I judge mine own wit good--
This Gloucester should be quickly rid the world,
To rid us of the fear we have of him.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: That he should die is worthy policy;
But yet we want a colour for his death:
'Tis meet he be condemn'd by course of law.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: But, in my mind, that were no policy:
The king will labour still to save his life,
The commons haply rise, to save his life;
And yet we have but trivial argument,
More than mistrust, that shows him worthy death.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: So that, by this, you would not have him die.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Ah, York, no man alive so fain as I!

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: 'Tis York that hath more reason for his death.
But, my lord cardinal, and you, my Lord of Suffolk,
Say as you think, and speak it from your souls,
Were't not all one, an empty eagle were set
To guard the chicken from a hungry kite,
As place Duke Humphrey for the king's protector?

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: So the poor chicken should be sure of death.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Madam, 'tis true; and were't not madness, then,
To make the fox surveyor of the fold?
