Who being accused a crafty murderer,
His guilt should be but idly posted over,
Because his purpose is not executed.
No; let him die, in that he is a fox,
By nature proved an enemy to the flock,
Before his chaps be stain'd with crimson blood,
As Humphrey, proved by reasons, to my liege.
And do not stand on quillets how to slay him:
Be it by gins, by snares, by subtlety,
Sleeping or waking, 'tis no matter how,
So he be dead; for that is good deceit
Which mates him first that first intends deceit.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Thrice-noble Suffolk, 'tis resolutely spoke.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Not resolute, except so much were done;
For things are often spoke and seldom meant:
But that my heart accordeth with my tongue,
Seeing the deed is meritorious,
And to preserve my sovereign from his foe,
Say but the word, and I will be his priest.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: But I would have him dead, my Lord of Suffolk,
Ere you can take due orders for a priest:
Say you consent and censure well the deed,
And I'll provide his executioner,
I tender so the safety of my liege.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Here is my hand, the deed is worthy doing.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: And so say I.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: And I and now we three have spoke it,
It skills not greatly who impugns our doom.

linegroup.speaker: Post
linegroup.line: Great lords, from Ireland am I come amain,
To signify that rebels there are up
And put the Englishmen unto the sword:
Send succors, lords, and stop the rage betime,
Before the wound do grow uncurable;
For, being green, there is great hope of help.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: A breach that craves a quick expedient stop!
What counsel give you in this weighty cause?

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: That Somerset be sent as regent thither:
'Tis meet that lucky ruler be employ'd;
Witness the fortune he hath had in France.

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: If York, with all his far-fet policy,
Had been the regent there instead of me,
He never would have stay'd in France so long.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: No, not to lose it all, as thou hast done:
I rather would have lost my life betimes
Than bring a burthen of dishonour home
By staying there so long till all were lost.
Show me one scar character'd on thy skin:
Men's flesh preserved so whole do seldom win.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Nay, then, this spark will prove a raging fire,
If wind and fuel be brought to feed it with:
No more, good York; sweet Somerset, be still:
Thy fortune, York, hadst thou been regent there,
Might happily have proved far worse than his.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: What, worse than nought? nay, then, a shame take all!

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: And, in the number, thee that wishest shame!

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: My Lord of York, try what your fortune is.
The uncivil kerns of Ireland are in arms
And temper clay with blood of Englishmen:
To Ireland will you lead a band of men,
Collected choicely, from each county some,
And try your hap against the Irishmen?

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: I will, my lord, so please his majesty.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Why, our authority is his consent,
And what we do establish he confirms:
Then, noble York, take thou this task in hand.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: I am content: provide me soldiers, lords,
Whiles I take order for mine own affairs.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: A charge, Lord York, that I will see perform'd.
But now return we to the false Duke Humphrey.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: No more of him; for I will deal with him
That henceforth he shall trouble us no more.
And so break off; the day is almost spent:
Lord Suffolk, you and I must talk of that event.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: My Lord of Suffolk, within fourteen days
At Bristol I expect my soldiers;
For there I'll ship them all for Ireland.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: I'll see it truly done, my Lord of York.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Now, York, or never, steel thy fearful thoughts,
And change misdoubt to resolution:
Be that thou hopest to be, or what thou art
Resign to death; it is not worth the enjoying:
Let pale-faced fear keep with the mean-born man,
And find no harbour in a royal heart.
Faster than spring-time showers comes thought
on thought,
And not a thought but thinks on dignity.
My brain more busy than the labouring spider
Weaves tedious snares to trap mine enemies.
Well, nobles, well, 'tis politicly done,
To send me packing with an host of men:
I fear me you but warm the starved snake,
Who, cherish'd in your breasts, will sting
your hearts.
'Twas men I lack'd and you will give them me:
I take it kindly; and yet be well assured
You put sharp weapons in a madman's hands.
Whiles I in Ireland nourish a mighty band,
I will stir up in England some black storm
Shall blow ten thousand souls to heaven or hell;
And this fell tempest shall not cease to rage
Until the golden circuit on my head,
Like to the glorious sun's transparent beams,
Do calm the fury of this mad-bred flaw.
And, for a minister of my intent,
I have seduced a headstrong Kentishman,
John Cade of Ashford,
To make commotion, as full well he can,
Under the title of John Mortimer.
In Ireland have I seen this stubborn Cade
Oppose himself against a troop of kerns,
And fought so long, till that his thighs with darts
Were almost like a sharp-quill'd porpentine;
And, in the end being rescued, I have seen
Him caper upright like a wild Morisco,
Shaking the bloody darts as he his bells.
Full often, like a shag-hair'd crafty kern,
Hath he conversed with the enemy,
And undiscover'd come to me again
And given me notice of their villanies.
This devil here shall be my substitute;
For that John Mortimer, which now is dead,
In face, in gait, in speech, he doth resemble:
By this I shall perceive the commons' mind,
How they affect the house and claim of York.
Say he be taken, rack'd and tortured,
I know no pain they can inflict upon him
Will make him say I moved him to those arms.
Say that he thrive, as 'tis great like he will,
Why, then from Ireland come I with my strength
And reap the harvest which that rascal sow'd;
For Humphrey being dead, as he shall be,
And Henry put apart, the next for me.

section.title: SCENE II. Bury St. Edmund's. A room of state.

linegroup.speaker: First Murderer
linegroup.line: Run to my Lord of Suffolk; let him know
We have dispatch'd the duke, as he commanded.

linegroup.speaker: Second Murderer
linegroup.line: O that it were to do! What have we done?
Didst ever hear a man so penitent?

linegroup.speaker: First Murder
linegroup.line: Here comes my lord.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Now, sirs, have you dispatch'd this thing?

linegroup.speaker: First Murderer
linegroup.line: Ay, my good lord, he's dead.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Why, that's well said. Go, get you to my house;
I will reward you for this venturous deed.
The king and all the peers are here at hand.
Have you laid fair the bed? Is all things well,
According as I gave directions?

linegroup.speaker: First Murderer
linegroup.line: 'Tis, my good lord.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Away! be gone.

section.para: Sound trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, CARDINAL, SOMERSET, with Attendants

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Go, call our uncle to our presence straight;
Say we intend to try his grace to-day.
If he be guilty, as 'tis published.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: I'll call him presently, my noble lord.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Lords, take your places; and, I pray you all,
Proceed no straiter 'gainst our uncle Gloucester
Than from true evidence of good esteem
He be approved in practise culpable.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: God forbid any malice should prevail,
That faultless may condemn a nobleman!
Pray God he may acquit him of suspicion!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: I thank thee, Meg; these words content me much.
How now! why look'st thou pale? why tremblest thou?
Where is our uncle? what's the matter, Suffolk?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Dead in his bed, my lord; Gloucester is dead.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Marry, God forfend!

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: God's secret judgment: I did dream to-night
The duke was dumb and could not speak a word.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: How fares my lord? Help, lords! the king is dead.

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: Rear up his body; wring him by the nose.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Run, go, help, help! O Henry, ope thine eyes!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: He doth revive again: madam, be patient.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: O heavenly God!

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: How fares my gracious lord?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Comfort, my sovereign! gracious Henry, comfort!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: What, doth my Lord of Suffolk comfort me?
Came he right now to sing a raven's note,
Whose dismal tune bereft my vital powers;
And thinks he that the chirping of a wren,
By crying comfort from a hollow breast,
Can chase away the first-conceived sound?
Hide not thy poison with such sugar'd words;
Lay not thy hands on me; forbear, I say;
Their touch affrights me as a serpent's sting.
Thou baleful messenger, out of my sight!
Upon thy eye-balls murderous tyranny
Sits in grim majesty, to fright the world.
Look not upon me, for thine eyes are wounding:
Yet do not go away: come, basilisk,
And kill the innocent gazer with thy sight;
For in the shade of death I shall find joy;
In life but double death, now Gloucester's dead.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Why do you rate my Lord of Suffolk thus?
Although the duke was enemy to him,
Yet he most Christian-like laments his death:
And for myself, foe as he was to me,
Might liquid tears or heart-offending groans
Or blood-consuming sighs recall his life,
I would be blind with weeping, sick with groans,
Look pale as primrose with blood-drinking sighs,
And all to have the noble duke alive.
What know I how the world may deem of me?
For it is known we were but hollow friends:
It may be judged I made the duke away;
So shall my name with slander's tongue be wounded,
And princes' courts be fill'd with my reproach.
This get I by his death: ay me, unhappy!
To be a queen, and crown'd with infamy!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Ah, woe is me for Gloucester, wretched man!

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Be woe for me, more wretched than he is.
What, dost thou turn away and hide thy face?
I am no loathsome leper; look on me.
What! art thou, like the adder, waxen deaf?
Be poisonous too and kill thy forlorn queen.
Is all thy comfort shut in Gloucester's tomb?
Why, then, dame Margaret was ne'er thy joy.
Erect his statue and worship it,
And make my image but an alehouse sign.
Was I for this nigh wreck'd upon the sea
And twice by awkward wind from England's bank
Drove back again unto my native clime?
What boded this, but well forewarning wind
Did seem to say 'Seek not a scorpion's nest,
Nor set no footing on this unkind shore'?
What did I then, but cursed the gentle gusts
And he that loosed them forth their brazen caves:
And bid them blow towards England's blessed shore,
Or turn our stern upon a dreadful rock
Yet AEolus would not be a murderer,
But left that hateful office unto thee:
The pretty-vaulting sea refused to drown me,
Knowing that thou wouldst have me drown'd on shore,
With tears as salt as sea, through thy unkindness:
The splitting rocks cower'd in the sinking sands
And would not dash me with their ragged sides,
Because thy flinty heart, more hard than they,
Might in thy palace perish Margaret.
As far as I could ken thy chalky cliffs,
When from thy shore the tempest beat us back,
I stood upon the hatches in the storm,
And when the dusky sky began to rob
My earnest-gaping sight of thy land's view,
I took a costly jewel from my neck,
A heart it was, bound in with diamonds,
And threw it towards thy land: the sea received it,
And so I wish'd thy body might my heart:
And even with this I lost fair England's view
And bid mine eyes be packing with my heart
And call'd them blind and dusky spectacles,
For losing ken of Albion's wished coast.
How often have I tempted Suffolk's tongue,
The agent of thy foul inconstancy,
To sit and witch me, as Ascanius did
When he to madding Dido would unfold
His father's acts commenced in burning Troy!
Am I not witch'd like her? or thou not false like him?
Ay me, I can no more! die, Margaret!
For Henry weeps that thou dost live so long.

section.para: Noise within. Enter WARWICK, SALISBURY, and many Commons

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: It is reported, mighty sovereign,
That good Duke Humphrey traitorously is murder'd
By Suffolk and the Cardinal Beaufort's means.
The commons, like an angry hive of bees
That want their leader, scatter up and down
And care not who they sting in his revenge.
Myself have calm'd their spleenful mutiny,
Until they hear the order of his death.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: That he is dead, good Warwick, 'tis too true;
But how he died God knows, not Henry:
Enter his chamber, view his breathless corpse,
And comment then upon his sudden death.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: That shall I do, my liege. Stay, Salisbury,
With the rude multitude till I return.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: O Thou that judgest all things, stay my thoughts,
My thoughts, that labour to persuade my soul
Some violent hands were laid on Humphrey's life!
If my suspect be false, forgive me, God,
For judgment only doth belong to thee.
Fain would I go to chafe his paly lips
With twenty thousand kisses, and to drain
Upon his face an ocean of salt tears,
To tell my love unto his dumb deaf trunk,
And with my fingers feel his hand unfeeling:
But all in vain are these mean obsequies;
And to survey his dead and earthly image,
What were it but to make my sorrow greater?

section.para: Re-enter WARWICK and others, bearing GLOUCESTER'S body on a bed

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Come hither, gracious sovereign, view this body.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: That is to see how deep my grave is made;
For with his soul fled all my worldly solace,
For seeing him I see my life in death.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: As surely as my soul intends to live
With that dread King that took our state upon him
To free us from his father's wrathful curse,
I do believe that violent hands were laid
Upon the life of this thrice-famed duke.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: A dreadful oath, sworn with a solemn tongue!
What instance gives Lord Warwick for his vow?

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: See how the blood is settled in his face.
Oft have I seen a timely-parted ghost,
Of ashy semblance, meagre, pale and bloodless,
Being all descended to the labouring heart;
Who, in the conflict that it holds with death,
Attracts the same for aidance 'gainst the enemy;
Which with the heart there cools and ne'er returneth
To blush and beautify the cheek again.
But see, his face is black and full of blood,
His eye-balls further out than when he lived,
Staring full ghastly like a strangled man;
His hair uprear'd, his nostrils stretched with struggling;
His hands abroad display'd, as one that grasp'd
And tugg'd for life and was by strength subdued:
Look, on the sheets his hair you see, is sticking;
His well-proportion'd beard made rough and rugged,
Like to the summer's corn by tempest lodged.
It cannot be but he was murder'd here;
The least of all these signs were probable.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Why, Warwick, who should do the duke to death?
Myself and Beaufort had him in protection;
And we, I hope, sir, are no murderers.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: But both of you were vow'd Duke Humphrey's foes,
And you, forsooth, had the good duke to keep:
'Tis like you would not feast him like a friend;
And 'tis well seen he found an enemy.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Then you, belike, suspect these noblemen
As guilty of Duke Humphrey's timeless death.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Who finds the heifer dead and bleeding fresh
And sees fast by a butcher with an axe,
But will suspect 'twas he that made the slaughter?
Who finds the partridge in the puttock's nest,
But may imagine how the bird was dead,
Although the kite soar with unbloodied beak?
Even so suspicious is this tragedy.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Are you the butcher, Suffolk? Where's your knife?
Is Beaufort term'd a kite? Where are his talons?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: I wear no knife to slaughter sleeping men;
But here's a vengeful sword, rusted with ease,
That shall be scoured in his rancorous heart
That slanders me with murder's crimson badge.
Say, if thou darest, proud Lord of Warwick-shire,
That I am faulty in Duke Humphrey's death.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: What dares not Warwick, if false Suffolk dare him?

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: He dares not calm his contumelious spirit
Nor cease to be an arrogant controller,
Though Suffolk dare him twenty thousand times.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Madam, be still; with reverence may I say;
For every word you speak in his behalf
Is slander to your royal dignity.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Blunt-witted lord, ignoble in demeanor!
If ever lady wrong'd her lord so much,
Thy mother took into her blameful bed
Some stern untutor'd churl, and noble stock
Was graft with crab-tree slip; whose fruit thou art,
And never of the Nevils' noble race.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: But that the guilt of murder bucklers thee
And I should rob the deathsman of his fee,
Quitting thee thereby of ten thousand shames,
And that my sovereign's presence makes me mild,
I would, false murderous coward, on thy knee
Make thee beg pardon for thy passed speech,
And say it was thy mother that thou meant'st
That thou thyself was born in bastardy;
And after all this fearful homage done,
Give thee thy hire and send thy soul to hell,
Pernicious blood-sucker of sleeping men!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Thou shall be waking well I shed thy blood,
If from this presence thou darest go with me.

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Away even now, or I will drag thee hence:
Unworthy though thou art, I'll cope with thee
And do some service to Duke Humphrey's ghost.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: What stronger breastplate than a heart untainted!
Thrice is he armed that hath his quarrel just,
And he but naked, though lock'd up in steel
Whose conscience with injustice is corrupted.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: What noise is this?

section.para: Re-enter SUFFOLK and WARWICK, with their weapons drawn

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Why, how now, lords! your wrathful weapons drawn
Here in our presence! dare you be so bold?
Why, what tumultuous clamour have we here?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: The traitorous Warwick with the men of Bury
Set all upon me, mighty sovereign.

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: To the Commons, entering Sirs, stand apart;
the king shall know your mind.
Dread lord, the commons send you word by me,
Unless Lord Suffolk straight be done to death,
Or banished fair England's territories,
They will by violence tear him from your palace
And torture him with grievous lingering death.
They say, by him the good Duke Humphrey died;
They say, in him they fear your highness' death;
And mere instinct of love and loyalty,
Free from a stubborn opposite intent,
As being thought to contradict your liking,
Makes them thus forward in his banishment.
They say, in care of your most royal person,
That if your highness should intend to sleep
And charge that no man should disturb your rest
In pain of your dislike or pain of death,
Yet, notwithstanding such a strait edict,
Were there a serpent seen, with forked tongue,
That slily glided towards your majesty,
It were but necessary you were waked,
Lest, being suffer'd in that harmful slumber,
The mortal worm might make the sleep eternal;
And therefore do they cry, though you forbid,
That they will guard you, whether you will or no,
From such fell serpents as false Suffolk is,
With whose envenomed and fatal sting,
Your loving uncle, twenty times his worth,
They say, is shamefully bereft of life.

linegroup.speaker: Commons
linegroup.line: Within An answer from the king, my
Lord of Salisbury!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: 'Tis like the commons, rude unpolish'd hinds,
Could send such message to their sovereign:
But you, my lord, were glad to be employ'd,
To show how quaint an orator you are:
But all the honour Salisbury hath won
Is, that he was the lord ambassador
Sent from a sort of tinkers to the king.

linegroup.speaker: Commons
linegroup.line: Within An answer from the king, or we will all break in!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Go, Salisbury, and tell them all from me.
I thank them for their tender loving care;
And had I not been cited so by them,
Yet did I purpose as they do entreat;
For, sure, my thoughts do hourly prophesy
Mischance unto my state by Suffolk's means:
And therefore, by His majesty I swear,
Whose far unworthy deputy I am,
He shall not breathe infection in this air
But three days longer, on the pain of death.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: O Henry, let me plead for gentle Suffolk!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Ungentle queen, to call him gentle Suffolk!
No more, I say: if thou dost plead for him,
Thou wilt but add increase unto my wrath.
Had I but said, I would have kept my word,
But when I swear, it is irrevocable.
If, after three days' space, thou here be'st found
On any ground that I am ruler of,
The world shall not be ransom for thy life.
Come, Warwick, come, good Warwick, go with me;
I have great matters to impart to thee.

section.para: Exeunt all but QUEEN MARGARET and SUFFOLK

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Mischance and sorrow go along with you!
Heart's discontent and sour affliction
Be playfellows to keep you company!
There's two of you; the devil make a third!
And threefold vengeance tend upon your steps!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Cease, gentle queen, these execrations,
And let thy Suffolk take his heavy leave.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Fie, coward woman and soft-hearted wretch!
Hast thou not spirit to curse thine enemy?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: A plague upon them! wherefore should I curse them?
Would curses kill, as doth the mandrake's groan,
I would invent as bitter-searching terms,
As curst, as harsh and horrible to hear,
Deliver'd strongly through my fixed teeth,
With full as many signs of deadly hate,
As lean-faced Envy in her loathsome cave:
My tongue should stumble in mine earnest words;
Mine eyes should sparkle like the beaten flint;
Mine hair be fixed on end, as one distract;
Ay, every joint should seem to curse and ban:
And even now my burthen'd heart would break,
Should I not curse them. Poison be their drink!
Gall, worse than gall, the daintiest that they taste!
Their sweetest shade a grove of cypress trees!
Their chiefest prospect murdering basilisks!
Their softest touch as smart as lizards' sting!
Their music frightful as the serpent's hiss,
And boding screech-owls make the concert full!
All the foul terrors in dark-seated hell--

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Enough, sweet Suffolk; thou torment'st thyself;
And these dread curses, like the sun 'gainst glass,
Or like an overcharged gun, recoil,
And turn the force of them upon thyself.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: You bade me ban, and will you bid me leave?
Now, by the ground that I am banish'd from,
Well could I curse away a winter's night,
Though standing naked on a mountain top,
Where biting cold would never let grass grow,
And think it but a minute spent in sport.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: O, let me entreat thee cease. Give me thy hand,
That I may dew it with my mournful tears;
Nor let the rain of heaven wet this place,
To wash away my woful monuments.
O, could this kiss be printed in thy hand,
That thou mightst think upon these by the seal,
Through whom a thousand sighs are breathed for thee!
So, get thee gone, that I may know my grief;
'Tis but surmised whiles thou art standing by,
As one that surfeits thinking on a want.
I will repeal thee, or, be well assured,
Adventure to be banished myself:
And banished I am, if but from thee.
Go; speak not to me; even now be gone.
O, go not yet! Even thus two friends condemn'd
Embrace and kiss and take ten thousand leaves,
Loather a hundred times to part than die.
Yet now farewell; and farewell life with thee!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Thus is poor Suffolk ten times banished;
Once by the king, and three times thrice by thee.
'Tis not the land I care for, wert thou thence;
A wilderness is populous enough,
So Suffolk had thy heavenly company:
For where thou art, there is the world itself,
With every several pleasure in the world,
And where thou art not, desolation.
I can no more: live thou to joy thy life;
Myself no joy in nought but that thou livest.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Wither goes Vaux so fast? what news, I prithee?

linegroup.speaker: VAUX
linegroup.line: To signify unto his majesty
That Cardinal Beaufort is at point of death;
For suddenly a grievous sickness took him,
That makes him gasp and stare and catch the air,
Blaspheming God and cursing men on earth.
Sometimes he talks as if Duke Humphrey's ghost
Were by his side; sometime he calls the king,
And whispers to his pillow, as to him,
The secrets of his overcharged soul;
And I am sent to tell his majesty
That even now he cries aloud for him.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Go tell this heavy message to the king.
Ay me! what is this world! what news are these!
But wherefore grieve I at an hour's poor loss,
Omitting Suffolk's exile, my soul's treasure?
Why only, Suffolk, mourn I not for thee,
And with the southern clouds contend in tears,
Theirs for the earth's increase, mine for my sorrows?
Now get thee hence: the king, thou know'st, is coming;
If thou be found by me, thou art but dead.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: If I depart from thee, I cannot live;
And in thy sight to die, what were it else
But like a pleasant slumber in thy lap?
Here could I breathe my soul into the air,
As mild and gentle as the cradle-babe
Dying with mother's dug between its lips:
Where, from thy sight, I should be raging mad,
And cry out for thee to close up mine eyes,
To have thee with thy lips to stop my mouth;
So shouldst thou either turn my flying soul,
Or I should breathe it so into thy body,
And then it lived in sweet Elysium.
To die by thee were but to die in jest;
From thee to die were torture more than death:
O, let me stay, befall what may befall!

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Away! though parting be a fretful corrosive,
It is applied to a deathful wound.
To France, sweet Suffolk: let me hear from thee;
For wheresoe'er thou art in this world's globe,
I'll have an Iris that shall find thee out.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: I go.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: And take my heart with thee.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: A jewel, lock'd into the wofull'st cask
That ever did contain a thing of worth.
Even as a splitted bark, so sunder we
This way fall I to death.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: This way for me.

section.title: SCENE III. A bedchamber.
section.para: Enter the KING, SALISBURY, WARWICK, to the CARDINAL in bed

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: How fares my lord? speak, Beaufort, to
thy sovereign.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: If thou be'st death, I'll give thee England's treasure,
Enough to purchase such another island,
So thou wilt let me live, and feel no pain.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Ah, what a sign it is of evil life,
Where death's approach is seen so terrible!

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: Beaufort, it is thy sovereign speaks to thee.

linegroup.speaker: CARDINAL
linegroup.line: Bring me unto my trial when you will.
Died he not in his bed? where should he die?
Can I make men live, whether they will or no?
O, torture me no more! I will confess.
Alive again? then show me where he is:
I'll give a thousand pound to look upon him.
He hath no eyes, the dust hath blinded them.
Comb down his hair; look, look! it stands upright,
Like lime-twigs set to catch my winged soul.
Give me some drink; and bid the apothecary
Bring the strong poison that I bought of him.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: O thou eternal Mover of the heavens.
Look with a gentle eye upon this wretch!
O, beat away the busy meddling fiend
That lays strong siege unto this wretch's soul.
And from his bosom purge this black despair!

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: See, how the pangs of death do make him grin!

linegroup.speaker: SALISBURY
linegroup.line: Disturb him not; let him pass peaceably.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Peace to his soul, if God's good pleasure be!
Lord cardinal, if thou think'st on heaven's bliss,
Hold up thy hand, make signal of thy hope.
He dies, and makes no sign. O God, forgive him!

linegroup.speaker: WARWICK
linegroup.line: So bad a death argues a monstrous life.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Forbear to judge, for we are sinners all.
Close up his eyes and draw the curtain close;
And let us all to meditation.

section.title: SCENE I. The coast of Kent.
section.para: Alarum. Fight at sea. Ordnance goes off. Enter a Captain, a Master, a Master's-mate, WALTER WHITMORE, and others; with them SUFFOLK, and others, prisoners

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: The gaudy, blabbing and remorseful day
Is crept into the bosom of the sea;
And now loud-howling wolves arouse the jades
That drag the tragic melancholy night;
Who, with their drowsy, slow and flagging wings,
Clip dead men's graves and from their misty jaws
Breathe foul contagious darkness in the air.
Therefore bring forth the soldiers of our prize;
For, whilst our pinnace anchors in the Downs,
Here shall they make their ransom on the sand,
Or with their blood stain this discolour'd shore.
Master, this prisoner freely give I thee;
And thou that art his mate, make boot of this;
The other, Walter Whitmore, is thy share.

linegroup.speaker: First Gentleman
linegroup.line: What is my ransom, master? let me know.

linegroup.speaker: Master
linegroup.line: A thousand crowns, or else lay down your head.

linegroup.speaker: Master's-Mate
linegroup.line: And so much shall you give, or off goes yours.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: What, think you much to pay two thousand crowns,
And bear the name and port of gentlemen?
Cut both the villains' throats; for die you shall:
The lives of those which we have lost in fight
Be counterpoised with such a petty sum!

linegroup.speaker: First Gentleman
linegroup.line: I'll give it, sir; and therefore spare my life.

linegroup.speaker: Second Gentleman
linegroup.line: And so will I and write home for it straight.

linegroup.speaker: WHITMORE
linegroup.line: I lost mine eye in laying the prize aboard,
And therefore to revenge it, shalt thou die;
And so should these, if I might have my will.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Be not so rash; take ransom, let him live.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Look on my George; I am a gentleman:
Rate me at what thou wilt, thou shalt be paid.

linegroup.speaker: WHITMORE
linegroup.line: And so am I; my name is Walter Whitmore.
How now! why start'st thou? what, doth
death affright?

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Thy name affrights me, in whose sound is death.
A cunning man did calculate my birth
And told me that by water I should die:
Yet let not this make thee be bloody-minded;
Thy name is Gaultier, being rightly sounded.

linegroup.speaker: WHITMORE
linegroup.line: Gaultier or Walter, which it is, I care not:
Never yet did base dishonour blur our name,
But with our sword we wiped away the blot;
Therefore, when merchant-like I sell revenge,
Broke be my sword, my arms torn and defaced,
And I proclaim'd a coward through the world!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Stay, Whitmore; for thy prisoner is a prince,
The Duke of Suffolk, William de la Pole.

linegroup.speaker: WHITMORE
linegroup.line: The Duke of Suffolk muffled up in rags!

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Ay, but these rags are no part of the duke:
Jove sometimes went disguised, and why not I?

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: But Jove was never slain, as thou shalt be.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Obscure and lowly swain, King Henry's blood,
The honourable blood of Lancaster,
Must not be shed by such a jaded groom.
Hast thou not kiss'd thy hand and held my stirrup?
Bare-headed plodded by my foot-cloth mule
And thought thee happy when I shook my head?
How often hast thou waited at my cup,
Fed from my trencher, kneel'd down at the board.
When I have feasted with Queen Margaret?
Remember it and let it make thee crest-fall'n,
Ay, and allay this thy abortive pride;
How in our voiding lobby hast thou stood
And duly waited for my coming forth?
This hand of mine hath writ in thy behalf,
And therefore shall it charm thy riotous tongue.

linegroup.speaker: WHITMORE
linegroup.line: Speak, captain, shall I stab the forlorn swain?

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: First let my words stab him, as he hath me.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Base slave, thy words are blunt and so art thou.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Convey him hence and on our longboat's side
Strike off his head.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Thou darest not, for thy own.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Yes, Pole.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Pole!

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Pool! Sir Pool! lord!
Ay, kennel, puddle, sink; whose filth and dirt
Troubles the silver spring where England drinks.
Now will I dam up this thy yawning mouth
For swallowing the treasure of the realm:
Thy lips that kiss'd the queen shall sweep the ground;
And thou that smiledst at good Duke Humphrey's death,
Against the senseless winds shalt grin in vain,
Who in contempt shall hiss at thee again:
And wedded be thou to the hags of hell,
For daring to affy a mighty lord
Unto the daughter of a worthless king,
Having neither subject, wealth, nor diadem.
By devilish policy art thou grown great,
And, like ambitious Sylla, overgorged
With gobbets of thy mother's bleeding heart.
By thee Anjou and Maine were sold to France,
The false revolting Normans thorough thee
Disdain to call us lord, and Picardy
Hath slain their governors, surprised our forts,
And sent the ragged soldiers wounded home.
The princely Warwick, and the Nevils all,
Whose dreadful swords were never drawn in vain,
As hating thee, are rising up in arms:
And now the house of York, thrust from the crown
By shameful murder of a guiltless king
And lofty proud encroaching tyranny,
Burns with revenging fire; whose hopeful colours
Advance our half-faced sun, striving to shine,
Under the which is writ 'Invitis nubibus.'
The commons here in Kent are up in arms:
And, to conclude, reproach and beggary
Is crept into the palace of our king.
And all by thee. Away! convey him hence.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: O that I were a god, to shoot forth thunder
Upon these paltry, servile, abject drudges!
Small things make base men proud: this villain here,
Being captain of a pinnace, threatens more
Than Bargulus the strong Illyrian pirate.
Drones suck not eagles' blood but rob beehives:
It is impossible that I should die
By such a lowly vassal as thyself.
Thy words move rage and not remorse in me:
I go of message from the queen to France;
I charge thee waft me safely cross the Channel.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Walter,--

linegroup.speaker: WHITMORE
linegroup.line: Come, Suffolk, I must waft thee to thy death.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Gelidus timor occupat artus it is thee I fear.

linegroup.speaker: WHITMORE
linegroup.line: Thou shalt have cause to fear before I leave thee.
What, are ye daunted now? now will ye stoop?

linegroup.speaker: First Gentleman
linegroup.line: My gracious lord, entreat him, speak him fair.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Suffolk's imperial tongue is stern and rough,
Used to command, untaught to plead for favour.
Far be it we should honour such as these
With humble suit: no, rather let my head
Stoop to the block than these knees bow to any
Save to the God of heaven and to my king;
And sooner dance upon a bloody pole
Than stand uncover'd to the vulgar groom.
True nobility is exempt from fear:
More can I bear than you dare execute.

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: Hale him away, and let him talk no more.

linegroup.speaker: SUFFOLK
linegroup.line: Come, soldiers, show what cruelty ye can,
That this my death may never be forgot!
Great men oft die by vile bezonians:
A Roman sworder and banditto slave
Murder'd sweet Tully; Brutus' bastard hand
Stabb'd Julius Caesar; savage islanders
Pompey the Great; and Suffolk dies by pirates.

section.para: Exeunt Whitmore and others with Suffolk

linegroup.speaker: Captain
linegroup.line: And as for these whose ransom we have set,
It is our pleasure one of them depart;
Therefore come you with us and let him go.

section.para: Exeunt all but the First Gentleman

linegroup.speaker: WHITMORE
linegroup.line: There let his head and lifeless body lie,
Until the queen his mistress bury it.

linegroup.speaker: First Gentleman
linegroup.line: O barbarous and bloody spectacle!
His body will I bear unto the king:
If he revenge it not, yet will his friends;
So will the queen, that living held him dear.

section.title: SCENE II. Blackheath.
section.para: Enter GEORGE BEVIS and JOHN HOLLAND

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: Come, and get thee a sword, though made of a lath;
they have been up these two days.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: They have the more need to sleep now, then.

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: I tell thee, Jack Cade the clothier means to dress
the commonwealth, and turn it, and set a new nap upon it.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: So he had need, for 'tis threadbare. Well, I say it
was never merry world in England since gentlemen came up.

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: O miserable age! virtue is not regarded in handicrafts-men.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: The nobility think scorn to go in leather aprons.

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: Nay, more, the king's council are no good workmen.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: True; and yet it is said, labour in thy vocation;
which is as much to say as, let the magistrates be
labouring men; and therefore should we be
magistrates.

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: Thou hast hit it; for there's no better sign of a
brave mind than a hard hand.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: I see them! I see them! there's Best's son, the
tanner of Wingham,--

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: He shall have the skin of our enemies, to make
dog's-leather of.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: And Dick the Butcher,--

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: Then is sin struck down like an ox, and iniquity's
throat cut like a calf.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: And Smith the weaver,--

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: Argo, their thread of life is spun.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: Come, come, let's fall in with them.

section.para: Drum. Enter CADE, DICK the Butcher, SMITH the Weaver, and a Sawyer, with infinite numbers

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: We John Cade, so termed of our supposed father,--

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Aside Or rather, of stealing a cade of herrings.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: For our enemies shall fall before us, inspired with
the spirit of putting down kings and princes,
--Command silence.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Silence!

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: My father was a Mortimer,--

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Aside He was an honest man, and a good
bricklayer.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: My mother a Plantagenet,--

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Aside I knew her well; she was a midwife.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: My wife descended of the Lacies,--

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Aside She was, indeed, a pedler's daughter, and
sold many laces.

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: Aside But now of late, notable to travel with her
furred pack, she washes bucks here at home.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Therefore am I of an honourable house.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Aside Ay, by my faith, the field is honourable;
and there was he borne, under a hedge, for his
father had never a house but the cage.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Valiant I am.

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: Aside A' must needs; for beggary is valiant.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: I am able to endure much.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Aside No question of that; for I have seen him
whipped three market-days together.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: I fear neither sword nor fire.

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: Aside He need not fear the sword; for his coat is of proof.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Aside But methinks he should stand in fear of
fire, being burnt i' the hand for stealing of sheep.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Be brave, then; for your captain is brave, and vows
reformation. There shall be in England seven
halfpenny loaves sold for a penny: the three-hooped
pot; shall have ten hoops and I will make it felony
to drink small beer: all the realm shall be in
common; and in Cheapside shall my palfrey go to
grass: and when I am king, as king I will be,--

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: God save your majesty!

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: I thank you, good people: there shall be no money;
all shall eat and drink on my score; and I will
apparel them all in one livery, that they may agree
like brothers and worship me their lord.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Nay, that I mean to do. Is not this a lamentable
thing, that of the skin of an innocent lamb should
be made parchment? that parchment, being scribbled
o'er, should undo a man? Some say the bee stings:
but I say, 'tis the bee's wax; for I did but seal
once to a thing, and I was never mine own man
since. How now! who's there?

section.para: Enter some, bringing forward the Clerk of Chatham

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: The clerk of Chatham: he can write and read and
cast accompt.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: O monstrous!

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: We took him setting of boys' copies.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Here's a villain!

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: Has a book in his pocket with red letters in't.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Nay, then, he is a conjurer.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Nay, he can make obligations, and write court-hand.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: I am sorry for't: the man is a proper man, of mine
honour; unless I find him guilty, he shall not die.
Come hither, sirrah, I must examine thee: what is thy name?

linegroup.speaker: Clerk
linegroup.line: Emmanuel.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: They use to write it on the top of letters: 'twill
go hard with you.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Let me alone. Dost thou use to write thy name? or
hast thou a mark to thyself, like an honest
plain-dealing man?

linegroup.speaker: CLERK
linegroup.line: Sir, I thank God, I have been so well brought up
that I can write my name.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: He hath confessed: away with him! he's a villain
and a traitor.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Away with him, I say! hang him with his pen and
ink-horn about his neck.

linegroup.speaker: MICHAEL
linegroup.line: Where's our general?

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Here I am, thou particular fellow.

linegroup.speaker: MICHAEL
linegroup.line: Fly, fly, fly! Sir Humphrey Stafford and his
brother are hard by, with the king's forces.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Stand, villain, stand, or I'll fell thee down. He
shall be encountered with a man as good as himself:
he is but a knight, is a'?

linegroup.speaker: MICHAEL
linegroup.line: No.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: To equal him, I will make myself a knight presently.
Rise up Sir John Mortimer.
Now have at him!

section.para: Enter SIR HUMPHREY and WILLIAM STAFFORD, with drum and soldiers

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
linegroup.line: Rebellious hinds, the filth and scum of Kent,
Mark'd for the gallows, lay your weapons down;
Home to your cottages, forsake this groom:
The king is merciful, if you revolt.

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
linegroup.line: But angry, wrathful, and inclined to blood,
If you go forward; therefore yield, or die.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: As for these silken-coated slaves, I pass not:
It is to you, good people, that I speak,
Over whom, in time to come, I hope to reign;
For I am rightful heir unto the crown.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
linegroup.line: Villain, thy father was a plasterer;
And thou thyself a shearman, art thou not?

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: And Adam was a gardener.

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
linegroup.line: And what of that?

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Marry, this: Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March.
Married the Duke of Clarence' daughter, did he not?

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
linegroup.line: Ay, sir.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: By her he had two children at one birth.

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
linegroup.line: That's false.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Ay, there's the question; but I say, 'tis true:
The elder of them, being put to nurse,
Was by a beggar-woman stolen away;
And, ignorant of his birth and parentage,
Became a bricklayer when he came to age:
His son am I; deny it, if you can.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Nay, 'tis too true; therefore he shall be king.

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: Sir, he made a chimney in my father's house, and
the bricks are alive at this day to testify it;
therefore deny it not.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
linegroup.line: And will you credit this base drudge's words,
That speaks he knows not what?

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: Ay, marry, will we; therefore get ye gone.

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
linegroup.line: Jack Cade, the Duke of York hath taught you this.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Aside He lies, for I invented it myself.
Go to, sirrah, tell the king from me, that, for his
father's sake, Henry the Fifth, in whose time boys
went to span-counter for French crowns, I am content
he shall reign; but I'll be protector over him.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: And furthermore, well have the Lord Say's head for
selling the dukedom of Maine.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: And good reason; for thereby is England mained, and
fain to go with a staff, but that my puissance holds
it up. Fellow kings, I tell you that that Lord Say
hath gelded the commonwealth, and made it an eunuch:
and more than that, he can speak French; and
therefore he is a traitor.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
linegroup.line: O gross and miserable ignorance!

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Nay, answer, if you can: the Frenchmen are our
enemies; go to, then, I ask but this: can he that
speaks with the tongue of an enemy be a good
counsellor, or no?

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: No, no; and therefore we'll have his head.

linegroup.speaker: WILLIAM STAFFORD
linegroup.line: Well, seeing gentle words will not prevail,
Assail them with the army of the king.

linegroup.speaker: SIR HUMPHREY
linegroup.line: Herald, away; and throughout every town
Proclaim them traitors that are up with Cade;
That those which fly before the battle ends
May, even in their wives' and children's sight,
Be hang'd up for example at their doors:
And you that be the king's friends, follow me.

section.para: Exeunt WILLIAM STAFFORD and SIR HUMPHREY, and soldiers

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: And you that love the commons, follow me.
Now show yourselves men; 'tis for liberty.
We will not leave one lord, one gentleman:
Spare none but such as go in clouted shoon;
For they are thrifty honest men, and such
As would, but that they dare not, take our parts.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: They are all in order and march toward us.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: But then are we in order when we are most
out of order. Come, march forward.

section.title: SCENE III. Another part of Blackheath.
section.para: Alarums to the fight, wherein SIR HUMPHREY and WILLIAM STAFFORD are slain. Enter CADE and the rest

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Where's Dick, the butcher of Ashford?

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Here, sir.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: They fell before thee like sheep and oxen, and thou
behavedst thyself as if thou hadst been in thine own
slaughter-house: therefore thus will I reward thee,
the Lent shall be as long again as it is; and thou
shalt have a licence to kill for a hundred lacking
one.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: I desire no more.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: And, to speak truth, thou deservest no less. This
monument of the victory will I bear;
and the bodies shall be dragged at my horse' heels
till I do come to London, where we will have the
mayor's sword borne before us.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: If we mean to thrive and do good, break open the
gaols and let out the prisoners.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Fear not that, I warrant thee. Come, let's march
towards London.

section.title: SCENE IV. London. The palace.
section.para: Enter KING HENRY VI with a supplication, and the QUEEN with SUFFOLK'S head, BUCKINGHAM and Lord SAY

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Oft have I heard that grief softens the mind,
And makes it fearful and degenerate;
Think therefore on revenge and cease to weep.
But who can cease to weep and look on this?
Here may his head lie on my throbbing breast:
But where's the body that I should embrace?

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: What answer makes your grace to the rebels'
supplication?

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: I'll send some holy bishop to entreat;
For God forbid so many simple souls
Should perish by the sword! And I myself,
Rather than bloody war shall cut them short,
Will parley with Jack Cade their general:
But stay, I'll read it over once again.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Ah, barbarous villains! hath this lovely face
Ruled, like a wandering planet, over me,
And could it not enforce them to relent,
That were unworthy to behold the same?

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Lord Say, Jack Cade hath sworn to have thy head.

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: Ay, but I hope your highness shall have his.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: How now, madam!
Still lamenting and mourning for Suffolk's death?
I fear me, love, if that I had been dead,
Thou wouldst not have mourn'd so much for me.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: No, my love, I should not mourn, but die for thee.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: How now! what news? why comest thou in such haste?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: The rebels are in Southwark; fly, my lord!
Jack Cade proclaims himself Lord Mortimer,
Descended from the Duke of Clarence' house,
And calls your grace usurper openly
And vows to crown himself in Westminster.
His army is a ragged multitude
Of hinds and peasants, rude and merciless:
Sir Humphrey Stafford and his brother's death
Hath given them heart and courage to proceed:
All scholars, lawyers, courtiers, gentlemen,
They call false caterpillars, and intend their death.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: O graceless men! they know not what they do.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: My gracious lord, return to Killingworth,
Until a power be raised to put them down.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: Ah, were the Duke of Suffolk now alive,
These Kentish rebels would be soon appeased!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Lord Say, the traitors hate thee;
Therefore away with us to Killingworth.

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: So might your grace's person be in danger.
The sight of me is odious in their eyes;
And therefore in this city will I stay
And live alone as secret as I may.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: Jack Cade hath gotten London bridge:
The citizens fly and forsake their houses:
The rascal people, thirsting after prey,
Join with the traitor, and they jointly swear
To spoil the city and your royal court.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Then linger not, my lord, away, take horse.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Come, Margaret; God, our hope, will succor us.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: My hope is gone, now Suffolk is deceased.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Farewell, my lord: trust not the Kentish rebels.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Trust nobody, for fear you be betray'd.

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: The trust I have is in mine innocence,
And therefore am I bold and resolute.

section.title: SCENE V. London. The Tower.
section.para: Enter SCALES upon the Tower, walking. Then enter two or three Citizens below

linegroup.speaker: SCALES
linegroup.line: How now! is Jack Cade slain?

linegroup.speaker: First Citizen
linegroup.line: No, my lord, nor likely to be slain; for they have
won the bridge, killing all those that withstand
them: the lord mayor craves aid of your honour from
the Tower, to defend the city from the rebels.

linegroup.speaker: SCALES
linegroup.line: Such aid as I can spare you shall command;
But I am troubled here with them myself;
The rebels have assay'd to win the Tower.
But get you to Smithfield, and gather head,
And thither I will send you Matthew Goffe;
Fight for your king, your country and your lives;
And so, farewell, for I must hence again.

section.title: SCENE VI. London. Cannon Street.
section.para: Enter CADE and the rest, and strikes his staff on London-stone

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Now is Mortimer lord of this city. And here, sitting
upon London-stone, I charge and command that, of the
city's cost, the pissing-conduit run nothing but
claret wine this first year of our reign. And now
henceforward it shall be treason for any that calls
me other than Lord Mortimer.

linegroup.speaker: Soldier
linegroup.line: Jack Cade! Jack Cade!

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Knock him down there.

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: If this fellow be wise, he'll never call ye Jack
Cade more: I think he hath a very fair warning.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: My lord, there's an army gathered together in
Smithfield.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Come, then, let's go fight with them; but first, go
and set London bridge on fire; and, if you can, burn
down the Tower too. Come, let's away.

section.title: SCENE VII. London. Smithfield.
section.para: Alarums. MATTHEW GOFFE is slain, and all the rest. Then enter CADE, with his company.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: So, sirs: now go some and pull down the Savoy;
others to the inns of court; down with them all.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: I have a suit unto your lordship.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Be it a lordship, thou shalt have it for that word.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Only that the laws of England may come out of your mouth.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: Aside Mass, 'twill be sore law, then; for he was
thrust in the mouth with a spear, and 'tis not whole
yet.

linegroup.speaker: SMITH
linegroup.line: Aside Nay, John, it will be stinking law for his
breath stinks with eating toasted cheese.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: I have thought upon it, it shall be so. Away, burn
all the records of the realm: my mouth shall be
the parliament of England.

linegroup.speaker: HOLLAND
linegroup.line: Aside Then we are like to have biting statutes,
unless his teeth be pulled out.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: And henceforward all things shall be in common.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: My lord, a prize, a prize! here's the Lord Say,
which sold the towns in France; he that made us pay
one and twenty fifteens, and one shilling to the
pound, the last subsidy.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Well, he shall be beheaded for it ten times. Ah,
thou say, thou serge, nay, thou buckram lord! now
art thou within point-blank of our jurisdiction
regal. What canst thou answer to my majesty for
giving up of Normandy unto Mounsieur Basimecu, the
dauphin of France? Be it known unto thee by these
presence, even the presence of Lord Mortimer, that I
am the besom that must sweep the court clean of such
filth as thou art. Thou hast most traitorously
corrupted the youth of the realm in erecting a
grammar school; and whereas, before, our forefathers
had no other books but the score and the tally, thou
hast caused printing to be used, and, contrary to
the king, his crown and dignity, thou hast built a
paper-mill. It will be proved to thy face that thou
hast men about thee that usually talk of a noun and
a verb, and such abominable words as no Christian
ear can endure to hear. Thou hast appointed
justices of peace, to call poor men before them
about matters they were not able to answer.
Moreover, thou hast put them in prison; and because
they could not read, thou hast hanged them; when,
indeed, only for that cause they have been most
worthy to live. Thou dost ride in a foot-cloth, dost thou not?

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: What of that?

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Marry, thou oughtest not to let thy horse wear a
cloak, when honester men than thou go in their hose
and doublets.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: And work in their shirt too; as myself, for example,
that am a butcher.

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: You men of Kent,--

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: What say you of Kent?

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: Nothing but this; 'tis 'bona terra, mala gens.'

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Away with him, away with him! he speaks Latin.

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: Hear me but speak, and bear me where you will.
Kent, in the Commentaries Caesar writ,
Is term'd the civil'st place of this isle:
Sweet is the country, because full of riches;
The people liberal, valiant, active, wealthy;
Which makes me hope you are not void of pity.
I sold not Maine, I lost not Normandy,
Yet, to recover them, would lose my life.
Justice with favour have I always done;
Prayers and tears have moved me, gifts could never.
When have I aught exacted at your hands,
But to maintain the king, the realm and you?
Large gifts have I bestow'd on learned clerks,
Because my book preferr'd me to the king,
And seeing ignorance is the curse of God,
Knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven,
Unless you be possess'd with devilish spirits,
You cannot but forbear to murder me:
This tongue hath parley'd unto foreign kings
For your behoof,--

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Tut, when struck'st thou one blow in the field?

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: Great men have reaching hands: oft have I struck
Those that I never saw and struck them dead.

linegroup.speaker: BEVIS
linegroup.line: O monstrous coward! what, to come behind folks?

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: These cheeks are pale for watching for your good.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Give him a box o' the ear and that will make 'em red again.

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: Long sitting to determine poor men's causes
Hath made me full of sickness and diseases.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Ye shall have a hempen caudle, then, and the help of hatchet.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: Why dost thou quiver, man?

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: The palsy, and not fear, provokes me.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Nay, he nods at us, as who should say, I'll be even
with you: I'll see if his head will stand steadier
on a pole, or no. Take him away, and behead him.

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: Tell me wherein have I offended most?
Have I affected wealth or honour? speak.
Are my chests fill'd up with extorted gold?
Is my apparel sumptuous to behold?
Whom have I injured, that ye seek my death?
These hands are free from guiltless bloodshedding,
This breast from harbouring foul deceitful thoughts.
O, let me live!

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Aside I feel remorse in myself with his words;
but I'll bridle it: he shall die, an it be but for
pleading so well for his life. Away with him! he
has a familiar under his tongue; he speaks not o'
God's name. Go, take him away, I say, and strike
off his head presently; and then break into his
son-in-law's house, Sir James Cromer, and strike off
his head, and bring them both upon two poles hither.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: It shall be done.

linegroup.speaker: SAY
linegroup.line: Ah, countrymen! if when you make your prayers,
God should be so obdurate as yourselves,
How would it fare with your departed souls?
And therefore yet relent, and save my life.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Away with him! and do as I command ye.
The proudest peer in the realm shall not wear a head
on his shoulders, unless he pay me tribute; there
shall not a maid be married, but she shall pay to me
her maidenhead ere they have it: men shall hold of
me in capite; and we charge and command that their
wives be as free as heart can wish or tongue can tell.

linegroup.speaker: DICK
linegroup.line: My lord, when shall we go to Cheapside and take up
commodities upon our bills?

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Marry, presently.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: O, brave!

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: But is not this braver? Let them kiss one another,
for they loved well when they were alive. Now part
them again, lest they consult about the giving up of
some more towns in France. Soldiers, defer the
spoil of the city until night: for with these borne
before us, instead of maces, will we ride through
the streets, and at every corner have them kiss. Away!

section.title: SCENE VIII. Southwark.
section.para: Alarum and retreat. Enter CADE and all his rabblement

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Up Fish Street! down Saint Magnus' Corner! Kill
and knock down! throw them into Thames!
What noise is this I hear? Dare any be so bold to
sound retreat or parley, when I command them kill?

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Ay, here they be that dare and will disturb thee:
Know, Cade, we come ambassadors from the king
Unto the commons whom thou hast misled;
And here pronounce free pardon to them all
That will forsake thee and go home in peace.

linegroup.speaker: CLIFFORD
linegroup.line: What say ye, countrymen? will ye relent,
And yield to mercy whilst 'tis offer'd you;
Or let a rebel lead you to your deaths?
Who loves the king and will embrace his pardon,
Fling up his cap, and say 'God save his majesty!'
Who hateth him and honours not his father,
Henry the Fifth, that made all France to quake,
Shake he his weapon at us and pass by.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: God save the king! God save the king!

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: What, Buckingham and Clifford, are ye so brave? And
you, base peasants, do ye believe him? will you
needs be hanged with your pardons about your necks?
Hath my sword therefore broke through London gates,
that you should leave me at the White Hart in
Southwark? I thought ye would never have given out
these arms till you had recovered your ancient
freedom: but you are all recreants and dastards,
and delight to live in slavery to the nobility. Let
them break your backs with burthens, take your
houses over your heads, ravish your wives and
daughters before your faces: for me, I will make
shift for one; and so, God's curse light upon you
all!

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: We'll follow Cade, we'll follow Cade!

linegroup.speaker: CLIFFORD
linegroup.line: Is Cade the son of Henry the Fifth,
That thus you do exclaim you'll go with him?
Will he conduct you through the heart of France,
And make the meanest of you earls and dukes?
Alas, he hath no home, no place to fly to;
Nor knows he how to live but by the spoil,
Unless by robbing of your friends and us.
Were't not a shame, that whilst you live at jar,
The fearful French, whom you late vanquished,
Should make a start o'er seas and vanquish you?
Methinks already in this civil broil
I see them lording it in London streets,
Crying 'Villiago!' unto all they meet.
Better ten thousand base-born Cades miscarry
Than you should stoop unto a Frenchman's mercy.
To France, to France, and get what you have lost;
Spare England, for it is your native coast;
Henry hath money, you are strong and manly;
God on our side, doubt not of victory.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: A Clifford! a Clifford! we'll follow the king and Clifford.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Was ever feather so lightly blown to and fro as this
multitude? The name of Henry the Fifth hales them
to an hundred mischiefs, and makes them leave me
desolate. I see them lay their heads together to
surprise me. My sword make way for me, for here is
no staying. In despite of the devils and hell, have
through the very middest of you? and heavens and
honour be witness, that no want of resolution in me.
but only my followers' base and ignominious
treasons, makes me betake me to my heels.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: What, is he fled? Go some, and follow him;
And he that brings his head unto the king
Shall have a thousand crowns for his reward.
Follow me, soldiers: we'll devise a mean
To reconcile you all unto the king.

section.title: SCENE IX. Kenilworth Castle.
section.para: Sound Trumpets. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, and SOMERSET, on the terrace

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Was ever king that joy'd an earthly throne,
And could command no more content than I?
No sooner was I crept out of my cradle
But I was made a king, at nine months old.
Was never subject long'd to be a king
As I do long and wish to be a subject.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Health and glad tidings to your majesty!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Why, Buckingham, is the traitor Cade surprised?
Or is he but retired to make him strong?

section.para: Enter below, multitudes, with halters about their necks

linegroup.speaker: CLIFFORD
linegroup.line: He is fled, my lord, and all his powers do yield;
And humbly thus, with halters on their necks,
Expect your highness' doom of life or death.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Then, heaven, set ope thy everlasting gates,
To entertain my vows of thanks and praise!
Soldiers, this day have you redeemed your lives,
And show'd how well you love your prince and country:
Continue still in this so good a mind,
And Henry, though he be infortunate,
Assure yourselves, will never be unkind:
And so, with thanks and pardon to you all,
I do dismiss you to your several countries.

linegroup.speaker: ALL
linegroup.line: God save the king! God save the king!

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: Please it your grace to be advertised
The Duke of York is newly come from Ireland,
And with a puissant and a mighty power
Of gallowglasses and stout kerns
Is marching hitherward in proud array,
And still proclaimeth, as he comes along,
His arms are only to remove from thee
The Duke of Somerset, whom he terms traitor.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Thus stands my state, 'twixt Cade and York distress'd.
Like to a ship that, having 'scaped a tempest,
Is straightway calm'd and boarded with a pirate:
But now is Cade driven back, his men dispersed;
And now is York in arms to second him.
I pray thee, Buckingham, go and meet him,
And ask him what's the reason of these arms.
Tell him I'll send Duke Edmund to the Tower;
And, Somerset, we'll commit thee thither,
Until his army be dismiss'd from him.

linegroup.speaker: SOMERSET
linegroup.line: My lord,
I'll yield myself to prison willingly,
Or unto death, to do my country good.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: In any case, be not too rough in terms;
For he is fierce and cannot brook hard language.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: I will, my lord; and doubt not so to deal
As all things shall redound unto your good.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Come, wife, let's in, and learn to govern better;
For yet may England curse my wretched reign.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Fie on ambition! fie on myself, that have a sword,
and yet am ready to famish! These five days have I
hid me in these woods and durst not peep out, for
all the country is laid for me; but now am I so
hungry that if I might have a lease of my life for a
thousand years I could stay no longer. Wherefore,
on a brick wall have I climbed into this garden, to
see if I can eat grass, or pick a sallet another
while, which is not amiss to cool a man's stomach
this hot weather. And I think this word 'sallet'
was born to do me good: for many a time, but for a
sallet, my brainpan had been cleft with a brown
bill; and many a time, when I have been dry and
bravely marching, it hath served me instead of a
quart pot to drink in; and now the word 'sallet'
must serve me to feed on.

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: Lord, who would live turmoiled in the court,
And may enjoy such quiet walks as these?
This small inheritance my father left me
Contenteth me, and worth a monarchy.
I seek not to wax great by others' waning,
Or gather wealth, I care not, with what envy:
Sufficeth that I have maintains my state
And sends the poor well pleased from my gate.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Here's the lord of the soil come to seize me for a
stray, for entering his fee-simple without leave.
Ah, villain, thou wilt betray me, and get a thousand
crowns of the king carrying my head to him: but
I'll make thee eat iron like an ostrich, and swallow
my sword like a great pin, ere thou and I part.

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: Why, rude companion, whatsoe'er thou be,
I know thee not; why, then, should I betray thee?
Is't not enough to break into my garden,
And, like a thief, to come to rob my grounds,
Climbing my walls in spite of me the owner,
But thou wilt brave me with these saucy terms?

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Brave thee! ay, by the best blood that ever was
broached, and beard thee too. Look on me well: I
have eat no meat these five days; yet, come thou and
thy five men, and if I do not leave you all as dead
as a doornail, I pray God I may never eat grass more.

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: Nay, it shall ne'er be said, while England stands,
That Alexander Iden, an esquire of Kent,
Took odds to combat a poor famish'd man.
Oppose thy steadfast-gazing eyes to mine,
See if thou canst outface me with thy looks:
Set limb to limb, and thou art far the lesser;
Thy hand is but a finger to my fist,
Thy leg a stick compared with this truncheon;
My foot shall fight with all the strength thou hast;
And if mine arm be heaved in the air,
Thy grave is digg'd already in the earth.
As for words, whose greatness answers words,
Let this my sword report what speech forbears.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: By my valour, the most complete champion that ever I
heard! Steel, if thou turn the edge, or cut not out
the burly-boned clown in chines of beef ere thou
sleep in thy sheath, I beseech God on my knees thou
mayst be turned to hobnails.
O, I am slain! famine and no other hath slain me:
let ten thousand devils come against me, and give me
but the ten meals I have lost, and I'll defy them
all. Wither, garden; and be henceforth a
burying-place to all that do dwell in this house,
because the unconquered soul of Cade is fled.

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: Is't Cade that I have slain, that monstrous traitor?
Sword, I will hollow thee for this thy deed,
And hang thee o'er my tomb when I am dead:
Ne'er shall this blood be wiped from thy point;
But thou shalt wear it as a herald's coat,
To emblaze the honour that thy master got.

linegroup.speaker: CADE
linegroup.line: Iden, farewell, and be proud of thy victory. Tell
Kent from me, she hath lost her best man, and exhort
all the world to be cowards; for I, that never
feared any, am vanquished by famine, not by valour.

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: How much thou wrong'st me, heaven be my judge.
Die, damned wretch, the curse of her that bare thee;
And as I thrust thy body in with my sword,
So wish I, I might thrust thy soul to hell.
Hence will I drag thee headlong by the heels
Unto a dunghill which shall be thy grave,
And there cut off thy most ungracious head;
Which I will bear in triumph to the king,
Leaving thy trunk for crows to feed upon.

section.title: SCENE I. Fields between Dartford and Blackheath.
section.para: Enter YORK, and his army of Irish, with drum and colours

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: From Ireland thus comes York to claim his right,
And pluck the crown from feeble Henry's head:
Ring, bells, aloud; burn, bonfires, clear and bright,
To entertain great England's lawful king.
Ah! sancta majestas, who would not buy thee dear?
Let them obey that know not how to rule;
This hand was made to handle naught but gold.
I cannot give due action to my words,
Except a sword or sceptre balance it:
A sceptre shall it have, have I a soul,
On which I'll toss the flower-de-luce of France.
Whom have we here? Buckingham, to disturb me?
The king hath sent him, sure: I must dissemble.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: York, if thou meanest well, I greet thee well.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Humphrey of Buckingham, I accept thy greeting.
Art thou a messenger, or come of pleasure?

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: A messenger from Henry, our dread liege,
To know the reason of these arms in peace;
Or why thou, being a subject as I am,
Against thy oath and true allegiance sworn,
Should raise so great a power without his leave,
Or dare to bring thy force so near the court.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Aside Scarce can I speak, my choler is so great:
O, I could hew up rocks and fight with flint,
I am so angry at these abject terms;
And now, like Ajax Telamonius,
On sheep or oxen could I spend my fury.
I am far better born than is the king,
More like a king, more kingly in my thoughts:
But I must make fair weather yet a while,
Till Henry be more weak and I more strong,--
Buckingham, I prithee, pardon me,
That I have given no answer all this while;
My mind was troubled with deep melancholy.
The cause why I have brought this army hither
Is to remove proud Somerset from the king,
Seditious to his grace and to the state.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: That is too much presumption on thy part:
But if thy arms be to no other end,
The king hath yielded unto thy demand:
The Duke of Somerset is in the Tower.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Upon thine honour, is he prisoner?

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: Upon mine honour, he is prisoner.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: Then, Buckingham, I do dismiss my powers.
Soldiers, I thank you all; disperse yourselves;
Meet me to-morrow in St. George's field,
You shall have pay and every thing you wish.
And let my sovereign, virtuous Henry,
Command my eldest son, nay, all my sons,
As pledges of my fealty and love;
I'll send them all as willing as I live:
Lands, goods, horse, armour, any thing I have,
Is his to use, so Somerset may die.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: York, I commend this kind submission:
We twain will go into his highness' tent.

section.para: Enter KING HENRY VI and Attendants

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Buckingham, doth York intend no harm to us,
That thus he marcheth with thee arm in arm?

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: In all submission and humility
York doth present himself unto your highness.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Then what intends these forces thou dost bring?

linegroup.speaker: YORK
linegroup.line: To heave the traitor Somerset from hence,
And fight against that monstrous rebel Cade,
Who since I heard to be discomfited.

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: If one so rude and of so mean condition
May pass into the presence of a king,
Lo, I present your grace a traitor's head,
The head of Cade, whom I in combat slew.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: The head of Cade! Great God, how just art Thou!
O, let me view his visage, being dead,
That living wrought me such exceeding trouble.
Tell me, my friend, art thou the man that slew him?

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: I was, an't like your majesty.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: How art thou call'd? and what is thy degree?

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: Alexander Iden, that's my name;
A poor esquire of Kent, that loves his king.

linegroup.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
linegroup.line: So please it you, my lord, 'twere not amiss
He were created knight for his good service.

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: Iden, kneel down.
Rise up a knight.
We give thee for reward a thousand marks,
And will that thou henceforth attend on us.

linegroup.speaker: IDEN
linegroup.line: May Iden live to merit such a bounty.
And never live but true unto his liege!

linegroup.speaker: KING HENRY VI
linegroup.line: See, Buckingham, Somerset comes with the queen:
Go, bid her hide him quickly from the duke.

linegroup.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
linegroup.line: For thousand Yorks he shall not hide his head,
But boldly stand and front him to his face.

linegroup.speaker: YORK
